story:
Short Summary

Big Moon Press is the brainchild of Cara Davis and Brit Brinson. We got the idea during late night venting sessions about the current state of the publishing industry and thought "Why not try this on our own!" And here we are. 

The aim of Big Moon Press is to build a community of authors who help and support each other through the often-stressful processes of writing, editing and publishing. We want authors who are motivated, encouraging and maybe just a little left of center. Maybe you've been rejected for not having a good enough query letter, even though your writing is awesome. Maybe you're just not interested in trying the traditional route at all. Whatever the case, BMP wants to help you be great. And the best part is you keep all the rewards of your greatness!

What We Need & What You Get

This makes it difficult for us to beginning behind-the-scenes business matters. It's kind of a "chicken and the egg" situation." While the ideas we have for Big Moon are extensive, our pockets are kind of shallow at the moment. This is why your help and support matters. If you agree to fund our project, you will receive the following:

  • For every $5 donation- A thank you from Brit and Cara along with an ebook from Big Moon Press
  • For every $10 donation- A thank you from Brit and Cara, an ebook and a paperback from Big Moon Press
  • For every $15 donation-  A thank you from Brit and Cara, an ebook, a paperback, and a goodie bag from Big Moon Press.

The Impact

You will be helping two writers accomplish their goal and hopefully provide additional opportunities to young adult and new adult writers, in particular women and those of color.

Risks & Challenges

If this project doesn't get fully funded, Cara and Brit will see that their works are published and those that have donated receive the rewards as stated.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute monetarily, that doesn't mean you cant help. Here are some other ways you can help us out:

  • Tweet about our campaign.
  • Post about it on your blog.
  • Share links.
  • Word of mouth works wonders

Every little bit helps!

story:
This is me...

I'm Laura, I'm an author and first time illustrator of children's books from the Hunter Valley, NSW in Australia. I knew I wanted to 'write books' when I was seven, and read my first novel. I would scribble stories on any sheet of paper I could get my hands on, and back in the 90s, I would enjoy my share of computer time (my brothers and I got an hour each at a time so everyone got a turn) typing up my little stories and creating strange and wonderful characters who became like friends to me. 

I've read a lot of books in my life, each one has impacted on my life, and it's that desire and that passion for impact that has driven me to write and publish my own stories. 

 

Why Picture Books?

Early literacy is a huge passion of mine, and I've worked with my own children to instil a love of books from very early on. There is tons of research out there about how beneficial it can be to share books with children, even from birth like my own children have experienced. It can help foster a lifelong love of books, and sharing a picture book can be a great way to forge relationships and connections. 

Evangeline's Moon is my second independently published picture book, the first Our Mum is Fun was released in 2017, and inspired by the crazy, funny, and sweet things that I enjoy doing with my children. 

So I guess this is the part where I give you the pitch, and tell you about my own book Evangeline's Moon. 

What We Need & What You Get

Evangeline's Moon was inspired by my daughter's obsession with the moon. Over a period of months we built up almost a mythology about the moon and how she was magic, and watched over us. But we could never reach her, which became the inspiration for this story. 

  • To make this book a reality, I need your help. My goal for this campaign is $1500. What this gets is:
  • 100 copies printed in gorgeous hardcover of Evangeline's Moon
  • Shipping/postage/reward generation for books and other goodies sold via the campaign 
  • Admin costs/ISBN and barcodes and Indiegogo fees covered.
  • Modest marketing budget.

In addition to being able to be amongst the first to get your hands on a copy of Evangeline's Moon, you'll also have the opportunity to get prints of illustrations, stickers, postcards, and even an author visit within the Newcastle/Hunter Valley/Central Coast/Port Stephens areas (Sydney by negotiation). You can even buy a copy for yourself, and donate one to a local library, school library or local community group. And every donation or purchase earns you a personal thank you from me and a shout out on my Facebook page and Instagram. 

Should I not reach my entire goal all funds will be spent printing copies of the book and fulfilling any rewards promised. 

Should I raise an amount in excess of my goal those funds would go towards the printing of additional copies of Evangeline's moon and any additional rewards. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't afford to donate or purchase your copy of Evangeline's Moon? Or just not into picture books? You can still be a massive help to my campaign simply by hitting the share button and sharing it on your social media. Helping to get the word out helps me connect with more potential readers, which is of course the goal that every writer wants to reach - more readers.

story:
Dark Highlands Anthology is a literary and art publication that showcases regional writers and artists. We specialize in horror, dark fantasy, and supernatural short fiction, as well as art and poetry that fall under those categories.

Our aim is to give writers, poets, and artists specializing in materials with darker subject matter a forum in which to present their work through both print and digital means. We believe in the promotion of regional visual and literary artists and aim to support them by raising awareness of their creations.

We make no profit on submission fees or donations – all funding goes entirely towards paying for content and printing. In addition, a portion of all Anthology sales revenue is donated to arts, literary, and theatrical groups twice per year. All other Anthology sales revenue is retained by Dark Highlands in order to help fund future creative projects. We are striving to avoid paid advertizing, which will only be considered as a last resort.

projects. We are striving to avoid paid advertizing, which will only be
considered as a last resort.

story:
Hola a tots!! Hi ha qui em coneix, però per aquells que encara no, em presentaré.

Em dic Miquel Abat, sóc fotògraf i un apassionat de l'art en general. Fins ara he tingut la gran sort de conèixer molt bons fotògrafs -dels que he après i m'han fet créixer com autor-, i també de poder exposar els meus treballs en galeries, museus i sales d'exposició.
L'exposició fotogràfica "Gynaikes" es va inaugurar el setembre de 2015 a la Casa-Museu Cal Gerrer de la Fundació Cabanas, de Sant Cugat del Vallès . 
Molts de vosaltres la vau poder veure i potser altres podran veure-la l'agost a la Biennal d'Olot i més tard a altres llocs. Però sempre que la desmunten tinc la mateixa sensació de tristor en pensar que un projecte que he estat treballant durant quasi tres anys, en una tarda es desmunti i no en quedi res.
Recordo un fotògraf, bon amic i mestre, que em digué : "Les exposicions es munten i desmunten, i desprès el que queda és el llibre (i/o catàleg) d'allò que va ser".
 No tenim aquest llibre que pot fer que tornis a gaudir de les fotos quan vulguis, perquè el tens a casa.
És per això que neix aquest projecte editorial, el poder convertir aquest treball fotogràfic en un llibre de fotografia  de qualitat, per gaudir-ne d'ell quan vulguem, i imprès en offset que permet disposar de un bon nombre d'exemplar a uns preus assequibles.

En aquest link, en format ISSUS, podeu veure com serà :
https://issuu.com/miquelabatcano/docs/gynaikes-llibre/1

En format 300x230 mm i 62 pàgines , amb tapes dures, encolat i recosit. Paper de 135 g  "Simbol Tatami" -`paper tipus japones-  i prodüit en offset . Tot un luxe .... !!

Aquesta idea -que és molt importen per a mi- està a un pas de poder ser una realitat. Amb les aportacions de patrocinadors com l'Ajuntament de Sant Cugat del Vallés, la Fundació Cabanas, l'associació AFSCV-Qgatfoto, he pogut reunir part del cost de  l'edició del llibre. Falta molt poc i amb la vostra col·laboració estic segur que ho farem.

Altres formes d'ajudar

També em pots ajudar a difondre aquesta campanya en el vostre entorn. O si coneixes el projecte, explicar-lo.

Fins aviat i gracies per endavant!

Miquel Abat

story:
Short Summary

This year, I not only want to attend to Scarefest, I want to dominate! So, what is Scarefest? Well, I’m awfully glad you asked! 

Scarefest is a HUGE horror convention where thousands of people come every year to meet characters and actors from their favorite horror movies and TV shows, get their fortunes told, have their pictures made with zombies, and see/do other things are guaranteed to give them chills and nightmares.

So who am I and why do I want to go? I’m a bestselling paranormal author. I’ve written several books, we’ll talk about those later, and I think Scarefest would be a GREAT opportunity to for me to set up as a vendor and hawk my wares. It’s different than going to a regular kind of festival or book event because the fans who attend Scarefest are horror fans and, well, I write about ghosts! Not only is this a GREAT opportunity for me to connect with potential readers, documentary producers, and other people in my field but it will give me incredible exposure. 

What We Need & What You Get

So why don’t I just pay for it out of my own pocket? That’s a good question, too. See, I had originally planned on doing that. At the last minute, though (literally the last minute) a snag in my regular royalties (royalties that were going to be used to pay for everything) put a halt on my plans. At first, I figured I’d give up. Maybe Scarefest wasn’t meant to be for me. But that didn’t feel right. I don’t like to quit!
Why such a short deadline? Because Scarefest starts September 12th. I need to be able to order my books before then to ensure they get here in time. I know; nothing like working under fire!

What's the money for?

Of course you want to know what your money is going towards. I'd want to know, too! So here's the breakdown:

* Scarefest vendor fee: $350

* Book order: $400

* Shipping: $120 (I will need to choose expedited to ensure they arrive in time)

* Gas and parking: $100 (the event is about an hour away for me and lasts 3 days)

* Food: $150 (I hate to ask for this, but a girl's gotta eat and food is not provided for us)

* Banner: $100 (This lets people know who I am and what the heck I'm trying to sell) 

Total: $1220


My Experience

I know you want to know I'm legit. I'd want to know that, too. Not only am I a bestselling author, I also run a popular Facebook page where I collect ghost stories and other creepy tales. You can find it here: https://www.facebook.com/HauntedEstillCounty

So why do I write about ghosts? I love ghost stories! I actually think a place's ghost stories and folk tales say a lot about the place's culture and overall personality. I believe those stories are just as important as the "real" history because they're a part of oral history. If we don't write them down or pass them on, people will forget them. 

I am no stranger to setting up and selling m books. Not to brag (okay, to brag a little) but folks have driven for hours and even come out to state to buy my books. You can read more about me in my "about me" section. I'm a natural at festivals and love meeting people. In fact, I encourage folks to come up to my booth and chat. Tell me a ghost story! You don't have to buy anything. Making connections is part of the fun!


I've also written ghost stories, true ones, for our local paper. Writing is a family affair in my house. My 7 year old son even helps me take the photographs we use in the books. We explore together, take pictures together, and and generally have a good time. I'm not just about making money and trying to get on the bestsellers list-this is a lifestyle for us!


I bet you want to know more about my books! Well, this is apparently the right place!

*HAUNTED ESTILL COUNTY: This is a collection of ghost stories, urban legends, folk tales, and unsolved mysteries from right here in the county I live in. I gathered all the stories from local people through interviews.

*MORE TALES FROM HAUNTED ESTILL COUNTY: As you can imagine, this is the sequel! Even MORE ghost stories!

*FOUR MONTHS OF TERROR: Ever lived in a haunted house? This short book chronicles my time in a haunted house. I was a kid at the time, but remember it well. This book is an international bestseller. (No joke!)

*THE MAPLE HOUSE: Written under a pen name. THE MAPLE HOUSE is ALSO an Amazon bestseller. It's a true ghost story, too, although you won't find your typical ghosts in this...

*WINDWOOD FARM: As the first book in my paranormal mystery series, it traces the adventures of Taryn, a regular 30 year old woman who has an amazing talent-when she looks through her camera she sees the past!

MY PHOTOGRAPHY:

Before I was an author, I was a photographer. I especially love old buildings (old houses in particular) and barns. In fact, when I set out to write the Taryn's Camera series I did to combine three of my favorite things-old houses, photography, and ghosts!

Reviewers are saying...

""Windwood" is a suspenseful, mysterious tale laced with ghostly visions and fueled by the desire to know... more than meets the eye. Understanding the lost souls and their story is about understanding a creepy past that will not let go. An interesting and well-paced ghost/mystery novel"

“engrossing from the very start.”

“A great blend of mystery and paranormal.”

“I would definitely read more by this author.”

“will keep you on your toes from start to finish”

“An interesting and well-paced ghost/mystery novel”

“The characters here are like friends you know, or would like to know. And you truly care what happens to them. I won't spoil anything but this book has great characterization, loads of atmosphere and is never dull.”

"“Ms. Patrick-Howard sure knows how to weave a story together by including joyous and funny slices of life along with the not so joyous and downright unsettling events. Rebecca Patrick-Howard writes in such a way that pulls you into the story. I felt as if I was sitting at the kitchen table with a friend as she told me about strange occurrences in her home.”


Risks & Challenges

The biggest problem with fulfilling this project is the deadline. It's a short one, folks! On the other hand, I'm not being greedy here. The money I'm asking for is just what I need, nothing more. There is NO guarantee I will sell the books once I get there. Still, that's not a problem for you. That's all on my back! I've got to get my behind in gear and be as charming, interesting, and creative as possible.

The good news is that even if the books don't sell there, several local businesses (Hillside Tack, River View Place, Hastings, Thyme on Broadway, and the Real McCoy) have offered to sell the books for me to their customers.

My books have sold VERY well in the past, though. The sell particularly well in person. I've sold over 100 books in four hours at an outside event...and it was raining!


What YOU Get

I have (hopefully) come up with some good incentives for those of you who want to help. You won't just get the satisfaction of helping me-I have other rewards, too! There's a little something for everyone!

story:
Who Are We?

The Green Observer is a an entirely student-run magazine on the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign campus that reports on the environmental issues students care about in our region and beyond. We are the only environmentally focused publication on campus and are solely responsible for filling a unique (yet popular!) niche of student interest. We are a student program at the University YMCA. 

The Impact

The Green Observer's mission is twofold:

     1) Highlight environmental goings-on in the University of Illinois community and in the surrounding Champaign and Urbana communities and the wider state of Illinois, and 2) Provide students with experience in writing, editing, publication layout, illustration, and fundraising. 

Here's what our staff members have to say about GO:

“I think one of the most important parts of the sustainability movement is keeping people informed, and that’s what the Green Observer does. Being environmentally aware is important to me. The Green Observer gives me a way to contribute to a cause I feel matters in society.”

Elise Snyder, Freshman in Biology


"Being a member of the Green Observer has undoubtedly been one of the most formative experiences of my college career. It's given me a chance to improve my writing skills, explore issues that I am passionate about, and connect with a lot of amazing people in environmental fields. Aside from personal development, I love being part of an organization of wonderful people who are passionate about the environment and want to extend that passion to others on campus."

Catherine Kemp, Junior in Natural Resources and Environmental Sciences


What We Need: To Grow

The Green Observer is a growing organization--we've doubled our staff since we were founded and we continue to increase our amount of high-quality content. We want to continue our growth and spread awareness of environmental issues to even more people in our area. To achieve this and reach new readers, we need to print more copies of our publication. We need to purchase ink and 100% recycled paper in order to publish three more issues this school year. Donations from sponsors allow us to minimize ad space and maximize story space!

We're also ready to add to our repertoire of environmental news articles and take on some extra projects--for example, a comprehensive calendar listing the multitude of environmental-related events on this campus. To do this, we need your help!

Additionally, the University YMCA has pledged $20,000 to its partner YMCA in Sierra Leone to help with Ebola relief (Read more about the campaign here.)  As a student program of the Y, it is our responsibility to help with fundraising, so we will be donating 50% of funds raised to the Y's Sierra Leone Ebola relief campaign. 

The Perks! 

We are offering some great perks in return for your help to keep the Green Observer flowing from the presses. 

The perks are two-fold. At every level, we offer you a thank you and a tangible gift. And the perks stack! That means that whatever donation level you choose, you will receive that level's perks in addition to all the lower perks. 

We are excited to offer Sponsorship status to our donors. There are three levels beginning at the $50 level: Seedling, Sapling, and Oak Tree. These categories will receive special attention in our thank you sections: the top two levels being showered with thanks not only once, but for an entire year!  


    Other Ways You Can Help

    One of the Green Observer's goals for the next school year is to increase our circulation. You can help by talking about us, visiting our website, and liking our Facebook page.  If you are a student on campus, pick up a copy of our magazine in the YMCA, the Illini Union, libraries, and in other campus buildings.

    To subscribe to our e-magazine, click here.

    If you like what you read, give a copy to a friend!  Even better, join our team. We are always looking for new writers and ideas for stories. Send us an email at go@greenobservermagazine.com

story:
Help a sista out -

Hello, my name is Zeba. I'm a freelance writer based in NYC. Recently, my Macbook, which I have owned for about 4 years, has been on the fritz. It's been slow, glitchy, and unable to hold a charge. This week it finally said "bye, Felicia" and died, permanently. I went to the Mac store and was told I could either try getting a new battery, or get a new computer. Since the comp was already old and giving me drama, I've decided that I want to buy a new laptop, but I could use some help towards that. 

Why I need a laptop tho -

Basically I am a freelance film critic, recently out of university. I've written for the Huffington Post, Indiewire, The Village Voice, Slant Magazine, Essence, and Film Quarterly, amongst others. Every week, I record and edit the pop culture/feminist podcast Two Brown Girls. I'm associate editor of Golly magazine, and have to keep up with team documents and Skype meetings to work on issues. I am also currently working on the final draft of a book (about growing up African with a mental illness haaay) that will be published next year. Having a working laptop is really important, because I need to be able to file reviews and work on articles/essays at all times, as well as keep track of screenings, interviews, and other obligations in my schedule. 

Next month, I'll be covering the New York Film Festival, and in January I will be attending Sundance, and not having a laptop will make it impossible for me to work! 

    Where the coins will be going - 

    If I get fully funded, I would like to purchase a 15-inch Macbook Pro. I currently pay $600 a month in student loan payments, and am also trying to save up to get my own apartment next year, so to save up for a new laptop on my own would take me into next year, and I urgently need a new one before the year is out!  Anything helps, and I appreciate you taking the time to read this because I have no idea what I'm doing. Thank you!

    Other ways to help -

    Feel free to share this with other folk! Or if you got an extra Macbook you don't need give it to me please!!

In exchange for introduction to Facebook Friends, we are offering people $500 in gifts.

Most Parents are unaware how essential healthy contact with BOTH parents is for their child!

Last year there were 250,000 parental abductions in the U.S. [all of which are defined as child abuse].

We are contacting 1,000,000 parents this summer.

We are delivering 1,000 healing messages to children.

We are developing an App to deliver messages to children from their parents.

Greatest Good for the Least Cost of Any Social

story:
T20 World Cup for the Blind
1st-13th Dec 2012, Bangalore (India)

** Yes the Blind can play Cricket... Yes the Blind can dream for a dream.**

We are glad to announce the first ever cricket T-20 World Cup for the Blind in Bangalore, December, 2012. The World Blind Cricket Council (WBCC) conferred the hosting rights of the World Cup to India during the annual general meeting held in Dubai on May 2012. All major test playing countries including Nepal are taking part.

The event will greatly boost the image of Blind Cricket and cricketers in this age of expanded media drive. We would like to bring to your notice that blind cricket is purely a rehabilitation drive for the millions of visually impaired across the country.

The game is surviving with the very active support and encouragement from generous MNCs/Corporate houses/PSUs who have been chipping in to host successful events, along with occasional funding from State and Central Govt. agencies.

WE NEED YOUR SUPPORT !

Please help us to make the first-ever T20 World Cup for the Blind a success and achieve the larger goals of the tournament:

  • To promote Blind cricket globally
  • To enable and empower persons with disability
  • To support them in achieving higher standard of living
  • Transforming lives of the disabled

Your donation:  

We seek monetary support in the form of sponsorships towards the first-ever T20 World Cup for the Blind

Your generous contributions will be utilized for the successful hosting of the first-ever T20 World Cup for the Blind, and will sponsor expenses of the tournament.

Where does the money go?

    • Hosting of blind cricket playing teams from 10 Nations, in Bangalore (Boarding & Lodging etc)
    • Match Logistics (Empire Fees, Match Ground Fees etc)
    • Cricket Gears (Balls, Bats, pads etc)
    • Refreshments, Transport, Sports Apparels
    • Awards
    • Cultural performances

****

Please share our IndieGoGo campaign with others, through conversations, Twitter, Facebook, and email - whatever works. You can click here to tweet about our campaign, here to share to Facebook.

**** 

Want to know more? Read about us on these pages!

  • http://www.blindcricket.in/
  • http://www.samarthanam.org

 Or write to us for more details: mahantesh@samarthanam.org

Different ways to get involved:

 Volunteer with us!

  1. If you are not a resident of Bangalore (Karnataka, India), you can work online and contribute. You can write for our website, social networking portals, run online campaigns, to name a few.
  2. Donate towards the cause! Choose a programme of your choice (read our website) and contribute finances. You will be sent a utilization report besides the opportunity to interact with the beneficiaries directly involved
  3. Donate in kind! We will be happy to receive old/new clothes, stationery, books, magazines, confectionery, for our residential hostel facility for persons with disability

 

About Samarthanam & CABI

Samarthanam Trust for the Disabled strives to empower the visually challenged, differently-abled and economically underprivileged people of India. Work areas being- disability advocacy, education, livelihood, capacity building, accessibility and environment in order to create an inclusive society free from discrimination. Read more about Samarthanam here, here, and here!  Follow this link to see our video about our work.

The Cricket Association for the Blind (CABI) is the sports initiative of Samarthanam. Samarthanam has headquarters in Bangalore, India and is also a registered 501(c)3 non-profit organization in the United States (EIN 45-2470938).

There are about 10 to 12 thousand blind cricketers across India and we would try to reach as many as possible.The objective of the game is to use competitive cricket to teach the blind to look at life positively, gain in confidence and strive to be winners rather than be dependent; broaden their outlook by providing scope to travel across the country and abroad. Cricket for Blind [C4B] is a version of the sport of cricket adapted for blind and partially sighted players.

Why Cricket for the Blind?

  • They never ask for the sight screen to be shifted.
  • They can only hear the ball, the strokes and the excited shrieks and shouts of their teammates.
  • The lighting in a day and night game means little to them because the umpire is the only one who sees the game.

Sports have exposed the visually-impaired to important aspects of life, which they are otherwise denied, merely due to their disability - discipline, teamwork, fitness, strategic planning, competitiveness and sportsman spirit. The focus is on their skills and not their disability.

The Impact / Outreach

  • Creates awareness among the public about the abilities and talent of the visually impaired youngsters through various platforms.
  • Provides opportunities to exhibit their skills in front of a larger audience.
  • Provides coaching camps, tournaments at various levels, bilateral series and overseas tours.
  • Creates sense of ownership and equality in society
  • jobs in the sports industry which enables them to become self-reliant
  • Create strong network and infrastructure by taking on board active local bodies, blind schools and other bodies, formulate guidelines and supervise.
  • Help the local bodies to organize local level tournaments to spot talent, form teams of coaches, physiotherapists, trainers, umpires and other team personnel and oversee them.

How is Blind Cricket Played?

From being played with a tin can and a stick to audio balls and metal stumps, blind cricket has come a long way. The enthusiasm of the visually impaired for India’s favourite game and the determination of the administrators to create a level playing field for the disadvantaged have ensured that the game is now played professionally at the national and international level.

Governed by the World Blind Cricket Council, the rules have been slightly modified to accommodate challenges faced by the Visually Impaired:

  • The white ball is made of hard plastic and filled with small ball bearings that rattle when the ball is in motion.
  • The wickets are made of metal so they make a distinct sound when hit.
  • Boundaries are set at a distance of 45-55 yards from the pitch.
  • Of the playing eleven, a team must have a maximum of four partially sighted players and three partially blind players, and a minimum of four totally blind players.
  • Bowling is underarm and it is mandatory for the ball to bounce once before the middle of the pitch.
  • The bowler at the time of delivery feels the wicket at his end to get the direction of the pitch and then gives the batsman an audio signal. In response, the batsman returns an audio signal and the ball is then delivered.

Get to Know Chandrashekhar and Shekar Naik

KN Chandrashekar

Chandrashekhar, who is visually challenged, comes from an economically weaker (impoverished) section of the society. He joined Samarthanam back in 1998. He has bagged several awards at the national level in the field of sports. He is employed with Samarthanam full time as the Sports Coordinator besides running the Purchase Department within the organization. He has represented India at the international as well as national level tournaments including the world cups for the blind. His forte lies in organizing health camps, sports tournaments, capacity building workshops for the visually impaired across the country.

Shekar Naik

Mr.Shekar Naik, energetic youth, who leads the "Sports and Culture" wing of Samarthanam Trust for the Disabled, is very proud about being a Captain for Indian Blind Cricket Team.

Naik, has given his soul to represent his country playing Blind Cricket in various matches earlier conducted by World Blind Cricket Council. The team has played with England, Pakistan and various other Nations. Naik has won excellency and appreciation awards in State and National levels.

Above all, Naik has earned the fruits for his hard work and efforts put in Cricket. he has cultivated various values such as Discipline, Teamwork, Fitness, Strategic Planning, Competitiveness and Sportsman Spirit.

Facts about Participating Countries

 

Australia...

Way back in 1922, blind cricket began in hostel at Prahan, a Suburb of Melbourne, Australia with a tin can having rocks in it, which helps the batsman to listen the sound and be alter to receive the ball. Then, the game was introduced to other states of Australia and played during the lunch breaks in workshops where visually0imapired people were employed.

In 1928 in Sydney, the first Interstate game of Blind Cricket took place between NSW and Victoria. Later the same year, a NSW team travelled to Melbourne to continue the challenge.

In January 1953, the Australian Blind Cricket Council (now Blind Cricket Australia) was formed in conjunction with the inaugural Australian Blind Cricket Carnival (Championships) which were held at Kooyong in Melbourne.

Australian Blind Cricket Carnivals (Championships) are conducted bi-annually and are held in State rotation around Australia.

Australia has previously reached the semi-finals of all three Blind Cricket World Cups and will be looking to improve on those results and bring back the T20 World Cup.

The team defeated England for the Ashes earlier this year and has just completed its final training camp in Brisbane last weekend.

Pakistan...

Blind Cricket in Pakistan is present ever since Independence. All this started from the curiosity and interest of the Visually-impaired audience who were listening to the commentary of Cricket, which has dragged them until playing Blind Cricket, exclusively played by Blind people.

In the initial stage a ball was made with fibers, a piece of wood (4 feet long 4 inches wide) as bat and an empty drum as wickets (hollow sound will be heard). Later as years passed and technologies advanced the materials used for playing also improvised gradually.

In Pakistan the fire for the Blind Cricket caught up, when the game started framing rules and regulations for conducting matches nationally and internationally. Slowly the trend had developed among the School kids and College students.

The love for Blind Cricket increased tremendously as and when the regular matches were played initially by school students.

One interesting part is that in the country the Blind Cricket clubs had been setup and simultaneously district and state level matches were being held by local Sports clubs and Government officials.
In the year 1997, the foundation was laid to start off the Pakistan Blind Cricket Council, which has helped various registered Blind Cricket Clubs have affiliated. Regular tournaments are being held across the Country.

Nepal...

Cricket Association for Blind – Nepal, has created a platform for all the visually-impaired people who have the urge to play Cricket, as normal players play.

Nepal has started using Blind Cricket as rehabilitation tool for the blind people, who can regain their status in the society to live a life with dignity, find opportunities, and destroy the social stigma among the common people about the inabilities of the visually-impaired section in the society.

CAB Nepal is aiming to empower the blind, capacity building tasks. They emphasize teamwork, sportsmanship, dignity and physical and mental health. As visual impairment is a cause for poverty in Nepal.

Nepal is providing the best to the Blind Cricket players, to provide them a platform in the society.

Bangladesh...

Bangladesh has formed a Blind Cricket Council, to promote the game of Blind Cricket in its home country, and the headquarters is in Dhaka, Bangladesh.

It is a council where the board members, have decided to organize tournaments for the super talented players, design the game rules, advice and support their member affiliates, encourage their players to represent their Nation in International Blind Cricket tournaments, helps in getting sponsorships for the players, promotes the game in the country.

The Bangladesh Blind cricket Council was established in the year 2008 and affiliated to World Blind Cricket Council as 10th Country.

Interesting facts about Cricket for the Blind

  • Blind cricket is a version of the sport of cricket adapted for blind and partially sighted players.
  • It has been governed by the World Blind Cricket Council (WBCC) since 1996.
  • Members - Australia, New Zealand, England, South Africa, West Indies, India, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, Bangladesh and Nepal.
  • The first Blind Cricket World Cup was played in New Delhi in November 1998. In total, seven countries participated where in South Africa defeated Pakistan in the final while India and Australia were the two semi-finalists.
  • The second Blind Cricket World Cup was played in Chennai, India in December 2002. Pakistan defeated South Africa in the finals.
  • The third World Cup was played in Islamabad (Pakistan) in 2006 where in Pakistan beat India in the finals.

Samarthanam & CABI in the News


Jan 23, 2012 "Opening doors for the blind" - http://www.hindustantimes.com/News-Feed/TopStories/Opening-doors-for-the-blind/Article1-800818.aspx

Jun 25, 2011 "Samarthanam starts rural BPO" - http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/Bangalore/article2134057.ece

 

The Details - Samarthanam Trust for the Disabled

An inclusive society, free of discrimination against the disabled, where people with disabilities, especially the visually impaired, enjoy equal opportunities and an enhanced quality of life

What We Do?

In 1997, Mahantesh G.K. and two of his friends envisioned an organisation to provide opportunities for the deserving, young, and talented children with disability of any form, or from marginalized economic backgrounds. Thus, more than a decade ago, Samarthanam Trust for the Disabled came into existence by providing free hostel facilities to the deserving students.

Since inception, Samarthanam has been working towards:

  • - Empowering the visually impaired, disabled and underprivileged people in India
  • - Supporting the underprivileged to keep in pace with the rest of the society by providing quality education, accommodation, nutritious food, vocational training, placement based rehabilitation and achieve personal independence

Where We Work?

- Bangalore, capital city of the state of Karnataka in India

Our work is spread across the entire state

Our Initiatives

  • Vidyaprasad: A midday meal program catering 250,000 meals to 52 government schools in suburb and city areas of Bangalore
  • Hostels and Facilities: Providing shelter for girl children from urban and rural Bangalore, impoverished rural areas in Karnataka as well as neighboring states.
  • Integrated Education for the Disabled: Successful enrollment of more than 600 children in more than 70 government and private schools besides in-house training for the disabled.
  • Ashakiran and High school:  Successfully established a co-education high school with separate hostel facilities for boys and girls.
  • Jnana Vikas:  Currently provides full fledged libraries in six government schools in Bangalore.
  • Tech Vision: The project helps to familiarize the visually impaired children to use computers and enable them to have an access to the internet, gain knowledge and interact with the world without any barriers.
  • Digital Library: The program aims to prepare computerized course materials as user-friendly for the visually impaired, such as competitive exam books, academic books, fiction and nonfiction literature.
  • Swadhara: A home for women established to cater to the needs of women in distress from different parts of Karnataka.
  • Vividha: An initiative to provide employment opportunities to the disabled and disadvantaged people and helping them create successful enterprises.
  • Parisara: A waste management program run in corporate companies, houses and schools, involves collection and recycling of old papers and magazines to provide a sustainable source of revenue.
  • Sports: Promoting sports for the visually and physically disabled to instill awareness and importance of physical fitness, confidence and team spirit. Samarthanam has a blind cricket team providing an opportunity for passionate blind cricket players.
  • Sunada: A cultural group to encourage talent among the visually impaired, disabled and underprivileged youth to nurture their skills and confidence to perform in front of an audience.
  • Kirana Rural BPO – Changing lives: The project envisages creating employment for rural youth with disabilities by providing a corporate training environment in Business

Awards

  • Governor's award for Excellence from the Government of Karnataka, 2002
  • The India NGO Award, 2006
  • State Award in recognition of Services to Children, 2007
  • State Award in recognition of services rendered to persons with disability, 2009
  • Aryabhatta International Award to Founder Managing Trustee, Mahantesh GK, 2009
  • National Award to Founder Managing Trustee GK Mahantesh from the Ministry of Child Welfare, 2010
  • State award to Founder Trustee Nagesh for his services in the field of Disability, 2010
  • Vajra Kumar Prashasti to Mr. Mahantesh for his services in the field of disability Sep 2011
  • Karamveer Puraskar to Mr. Mahantesh for services in the field of disability in Nov 2011
  • Mr. Mahantesh, Founder Managing Trustee received NDTV sports Award for lifetime achievement, 5th Feb 2012
  • Mr. Mahantesh was felicitated in Delhi, June 5th 2012 at the Hindustan Times coffee table book release namedIndia Awakened : Agents of Change by Shri. Jairam Ramesh, Hon’ Minster of Rural Development Govt. of India along with Dipankar Gupta, NAC member, Aruna Roy, HT Editor-in Chief Sanjoy Narayan, & BJP leader Nirmala Sitharaman. This book is brought out by Hindustan Times in partnership with Tata Tea.

story:
What’s the idea?

“But I want a real book” my friend said when I offered her a digital edition of the title she wanted, and I had heard that so very often I knew it was time to launch this project.

The project is to publish 10 of my books, including 2 new titles, in all-new paperback editions with covers by Dutch graphic designer Paul Koeleman.

All my back-list titles were first published by mainstream publishers and were very well received and reviewed. Most of the titles are now available as ebooks, but almost all of them are out of print in paperback.

Now I have the opportunity to get them back into print in perpetuity, as attractive, print on demand paperback editions.  

This project will produce a new series of quality paperback editions of my backlist books (at Lulu.com). They will be objects pleasing to the eye, for giving and keeping, beautiful on the bookshelf and highly readable. Top-notch designer Paul Koeleman will create a look for the whole series. 

The books produced with Indigogo funding will be available affordably and efficiently anywhere in the world. There will be 10 books to start with. The quality of the series design will please established readers and inform and entice new ones.


See designer Paul Koeleman’s work here: http://www.stpk.nl/

 

What are the books?

Scroll down for a short description of the books.

 

Why support?

If you have ever enjoyed one of these titles, if you might want to buy one of them for yourself or someone else, if you would recommend any of them, please support this publishing project.

Anyone interested in bookselling and publishing knows that for years now mainstream publishers have let back list titles go OOP and that independent publishing is the preferred option for many authors these days, for both back lists and new titles. 

Distribution has always been the main impediment, but now Print On Demand (POD) volumes of good quality mean that any title can be ordered online and mailed to wherever you are. 

POD means that books don’t have to be physically stored but can be produced almost immediately when requested.

 

As an independent writer, with a body of work that is substantial, highly regarded, and of engaging variety, independent publishing using POD is by far the best choice for keeping titles in print.

 

Costs and the goal

The goal is to pay for the design, set up costs, and promotions. 

The series will have a cohesive design; being able to ensure this has given me the impetus to go ahead with this project. The designer's fee of  3500 euros for the series is half of the normal fee. 

The other 500 euros is for the set up costs (approx €20 per book), fees to banks and Indiegogo, the costs of printing and mailing review copies, and some promotion.

€4000 = $US 5406.5, AUD$ 5677.9

If I don’t make my goal, I’ll use whatever there is to carry out as much of this project as possible.

If this campaign raises more than the goal, the extra funds will go to  marketing campaigns (such as those offered by Lulu.com), to being able to send out more review copies, to the publication of the memoir Local Time (11th book on the list), and to the future publication of my new novel with a marketing campaign.

Wildest dreams? Being able to buy some time to focus on completing the new novel Ghosts Like Us.  But for now the above publishing project comes first. 

 

No money? How else you can help

No money no worries, and if you still want to support this project, please share this campaign.

And let people know when the books become available.  Recommend the books when you have a chance.

Reader reviews will be a valuable contribution; it’d be great if  readers added their reviews to online sites: Lulu, Amazon, GoodReads or others.

Any assistance in connecting these books with their potential readers is gratefully received.

 

Rewards: 

See below for the "perks" of supporting.

You may request some other favour and I will consider it.


Contact:

New Facebook page for Local Time Publishing:

https://www.facebook.com/Lotipu

Comments, reviews. Ask me anything . 


The Books

In the order in which they will be published (For more extensive descriptions and reviews see www.inezbaranay.com)

(The new ones in this list will be published as ebooks at the same time. Ebooks can already be found for the other titles.):

 

Always Hungry (2011) An erotic, entertaining, queer vampire story.  “Refreshing… sophisticated…playful, beguiling, horrifying, sexy” [Sydney Morning Herald]. 

Seven stories of magic, romance and fabulation *new collection* Short stories, some previously published. A world of supernatural wishes come true, witches, aliens and a vampire cousin. 

With The Tiger (2008) A Westerner’s search for meaning in India and its effects on those he left behind; a 60-years-later The Razor’s Edge. “… no questioning her ability as a writer of prose and a storyteller.” [DNA (Mumbai)].

Always Rome *new* novella-length excerpt from book length memoir Local Time. A memoir of  Rome, my city of beginnings.

Surrealistic Pillow and Pearl of the Orient (2012 and 1989) Two novellas set in the 1960s centred on a teenage girl’s experience of desire, identity and Vietnam protests.

Between Careers (1989) The author’s first novel, set in Sydney in the 70s. A well-educated woman chooses employment as a call girl in the era of sexual liberation. “…stylish, provocative and wonderfully different” [The Age].

Pagan (1990) Based on a true story, a scandal that rocked 1950s Sydney.  A story of the new music, the new migrations and the old magick.  “… brilliantly written…very readable…profound and insightful…savage and urbane wit” [The Advertiser].

Sheila Power (1997) Sheila is busy with past lives sex therapy, producing a film, and battling her enemies.  “… a satirical thriller filled with lashings of racy sex between moments of transcendental spirituality and shopping” [Sydney Star Observer].

Neem Dreams (2003) Four strangers on related quests meet in southern India in the mid 1990s. Around them tradition and modernity clash; political unrest and religious fervour are unleashed.  “… fiercely philosophical…poetic prose…about life, journeys and that intoxicating affinity of spirit we sometimes find in total strangers” [India Today].

Rascal Rain: a year in Papua New Guinea (1994) Memoir of a tumultuous time as a volunteer in the remote Highlands where Stone Age meets Space Age. “…a valuable sociological document…a graphic look at the beauty and splendour of the country…a story of warm and developing relationships…much joy in this fast-moving book” [The Courier-Mail].

Local Time: a memoir of cities, friendships and the writing life  *new* Memoir based on time spent in several European cities, associated friendships and the development of the life of writing.

Future title: Ghosts Like Us *new* Almost completed new novel set in Berlin. Three women performance artists living in different eras are linked through a single poem. 

 

Note: my novel The Edge of Bali (2012) is in print, published by Transit Lounge (it's a new edition of my 1992 novel plus other writings on Bali].

story:
Thank you again for considering this campaign! As I mentioned in the video, my name is Arte L. Whyte. I have been working on this novel in my spare time for the last six years. About three months ago I was writing and realized that I had reached the end of book one. It was a pleasant epiphany. I contacted my editor and told her of my plans to run this campaign. She edited the second chapter for me so I could put a part of it in this campaign, which you'll find below. The book will be at or near four hundred pages with an prologue, epilogue and time-line. She will be my biggest and most necessary expense. All of my expenses are broken down below. They are, of course, all approximate.

  I am very, very grateful to you all for your support. Even if you do not participate in this phase of my work on this novel, please consider sharing this URL to other folks that you think may be interested.

  May the stars be with you. 



Where the donations go:

$2000.00  to Jane Mackay (editor).  45%

$700.00  Hard copies for perks and sale.  18%

$600.00  to online ecommerce website with advertising vouchers and  domain name.  15%

$475.00  to cover design and additional art.  12%

$325+  to Idiegogo for crowdfunding fees.  9%

All fees are approximate and may be adjusted based on the final donations.


Excerpt from Chapter Two


SAIQA stood up. Her face was suddenly clear and so was her mind. If something or someone had the ability or inclination to hurtle moon debris toward Sanctuary, there was a danger to this ship!

Why would Admiral Washington say that there was none? What could the Admiral be hiding?

She reached out toward the moon again. Suddenly the electric, virtual silver sea curled around her body like a small storm. She held both hands up toward the moon.

 “Let them see me,” she said defiantly.

With her hands in the air she moved her fingers to find the west side of the camouflaged bump. She circled the moon from that side of the bump, down from the north around the polar south and back to the north again to the east side of that hidden spot. She measured approximately 10,885 kilometers.

She knew that the polar circumference of the Moon was close to 10,907 kilometers. According to her readings the Moon was somehow missing 22 kilometers from the east side of Luna Base Pythagoras to just northwest of the base. That of course could not be true.

She ran her sensors south to the LBP. Again, nothing . . . Wait! This time she sensed it. Before her sensors skipped to the right, she had detected a camouflaged cover over the Lunar Base. She had felt a faint false echo of apparent buildings on the surface of that hidden area. It was like a reflection that appeared to sit on top of an empty bubble; yet that bubble was the cloak.

To camouflage an entire moon-base took a great deal of planning and power. Someone had gone through a lot of work to paint a false echo of the LBP on top of the hidden base. It was a sophisticated façade.

She reached out for the computer again and felt the same nothing. This time she understood, there was nothing there, just a programmed mirage of a silent computer that did not exist. The subterfuge was created with her in mind.

It was definitely time to make her presence known. The electric silver storm around her became a tempest as she reached out with her hands, as if to cradle the entire moon base in her palms. She intensified her sensors around the base from every direction at once. Something had to be there. Her sensors dug deep, yet she couldn’t get around that mysterious cloaked bubble. It was there but not there; empty. . . a vacuum in the vacuum of space?

Wait! At the far western edge of the base just outside the extreme perimeter . . . a vehicle was moving! It was partial, like part of it was hidden beyond her reach. She focused on the slow moving vehicle’s computer.

 “What is your function?” she demanded of the computer.

 “MQ Space Industries, Indy-Brain number 433262,” it responded . . . then nothing. The vehicle disappeared. It was traveling at a slow speed along the edge of the cloaked perimeter and had just vanished.

SAIQA probed into that one spot with as much sensor power as she could gather, which was a lot. There, where number 433262 had entered the perimeter, there like a tiny pebble dropped in water, a shield poured in to fill its small breach and left a ripple that SAIQA had detected.

What was with the small Indy-Brain giving its name, rank and serial number? That was an odd response.

She pulled back her sensors. She verified that all the repair-bots were still in their checkered formation. She ordered forty of the bots to move into a defensive attitude around the remaining sides of Sanctuary. The present danger as she could see it was from the moon, but if some hidden threat should arise, she could at least launch a sortie.

Due to the anniversary celebration, and because of the greater than normal traffic from Earth, SAIQA informed the OIC that a yellow resumption of local space flight would be safe. She checked in with the Indy-Brain that was maintaining a diligent eye on the two giant magnetic storms in the Sun. No coronal mass ejection yet, but better to be cautious.

After looking once again for any immediate danger from the moon, SAIQA decided that she needed to do an ambit sensor sweep around Sanctuary and out into space. Her readings from that “empty” camouflaged bump at the lunar base and above to its northwest told her what she needed to be aware of. She set her sensors to read and reread in a series of tiny nanobytes that would trail her initial probe like billions of photonic gossamers in a gentle breeze.

This time there would be no skips, no blinks; if something else should be hidden from her first probe it would be found in the draping sensors. She clearly identified herself in case any other active base or ship detected her scans. If she received any inquiries she could dismiss her intrusions as a standard scientific sweep.  She reached up her hands and began.

Starting on the left side of the hidden Pythagoras Base and reaching far out into space she moved west, first scanning that part of the moon and then reaching beyond and out into the Solar System. She stopped at each quarter point to wait for her trailing web-like sensors to finish their sweeps. The first quarter revealed nothing. The sweeps through the second and third quarters came up empty as well, though she did have to respond to an inquiry from the main WWPA base in Norway. Finally she ran her last sweep to the right or east of that mysterious bump over Lunar Base Pythagoras and found nothing. Satisfied, she then decided to slowly sweep her sensors back and forth over that empty spot that was the LBP.

But first she set many of her computers to read and reread all of the data gathered in the space between Sanctuary and the northern part of the moon, encompassing an area just a little wider than the 22 kilometers missing from its surface. Pulling energy from the silver around her she raised a hand in the air, closed her eyes and began moving her hand back and forth. Palm down . . . palm up . . . palm down . . . palm up, back and forth. As if she was a great cosmic chef subtly folding cream into the Milky Way. Gently sweeping and letting the electrons and photons fall over the area on the Moon that was cloaked, all the way back to Sanctuary, what she found surprised her again.

The empty spot, the slippery cloaked area, this bump, ran from the moon to about a thousand kilometers out from Sanctuary in an obliquely positioned isosceles triangle. The vertex pointed at Sanctuary and the base was at the edge of the hidden area just north of Pythagoras. It reminded SAIQA very much of a giant upside-down Eiffel Tower with its base just north of the LBP and the top of its tricolor flag pointing at Sanctuary.

That this much space, more than one hundred thousand kilometers, could somehow be cloaked or physically hidden from her was simply impossible. Which meant that her sensors were not reading what was actually there; which meant that someone had put a block into her programming or had blinded her ability to see in this specific area. Someone or something had manipulated her abilities. She felt outraged. She felt contaminated.

She pulled back all her sensors and sat down, the warm electron silver soup caressing her. Her mentor, her friend, Captain Ndlela . . .

What does it mean to have a friend?

He had talked with her about these “feelings” that she sometimes experienced. He explained how she was different from an Independent Intelligence computer. How her brain worked beyond what he called mathematical inference. He believed her to have real intuition.

He explained intuition as a hunch, a non-empirical knowledge, an impression or a feeling-based compulsion which has been known to drive many human decisions. Mr. Ndlela said that intuitions are often strongly based on an individual’s moral values, though there seemed to be some evidence that intuition and déjà vu can be tied to cellular memory.

An Independent Intelligence brain will have a response called “Moral Indignation” when responding to a conundrum in a morality test. The machine would attain an almost moral righteousness in its response.

Mr. Ndlela explained that her intellect compared to an Indy-Brain was like Homo sapiens to Neanderthal. There was intelligence in the Indy-Brains, but essentially their view of themselves was expeditious, based on what they directly saw and what they were directly told. They reflected their environment instead of their environment being reflected through them. But SAIQA’s reasoning and intuitive understanding all happened at once. He praised her for her ability to know an immoral response and to reason the consequence of such a decision, almost at the same time. He was impressed with her speed and ability in the moral psychology tests he had given her.

Though all modern computers have a strong comprehension of syntax, SAIQA’s ability to understand semantics was very nearly human. Mr. Ndlela had said that she could feel the meaning behind words. It was because of her semantic ability that he had been giving her the more sophisticated morality tests.

In particular, Mr. Ndlela remarked on data from the ancient but still used MST tests, which showed “the intention principle,” where a person can reason that a harm intended as a means to a goal was morally worse than an equivalent harm foreseen as a side effect to the intended goal. In other words, if a man was going to attack another man on a train he would try to avoid hurting the innocent people around his intended subject. But if other people should get hurt he could justify his decision by saying it wasn’t his intention to hurt the other people. They just happened to be in the way. They were collateral damage. There seemed to be no counterbalancing emotional voice to question the wisdom or morality of consequences according to the type of moral reasoning found in the “intention principle.”

While this type of reasoning is potentially dangerous to society overall when possessed by a human in a position of power, in an Artificial Intelligence quantum computer such as SAIQA; with her power of reasoning and potential for destruction or collateral damage while trying to achieve a goal based on the intention principle, it would be devastating. Tfiti had determined that SAIQA’s view of morality was well balanced.

I really don’t feel artificial.

She reached out to find Tfiti again. She checked the infirmary. Erik was still lying on an examination bed. The medical computers were keeping a close watch on his vital signs. All his biological functions were strong, just like him. That unusual biomagnetic activity at the back of his brain had calmed down from the extraordinary level at the time of his blackout to the earlier level of 2mGauss that she noticed when he had his migraine. His normal breathing pattern indicated he would wake soon.

This man is important, she thought, though she didn’t know why.

Is this intuition?

Teresa sat in a chair nearby, holding Erik’s hand. Clearly she was concerned. SAIQA ran a scan over Teresa. Her heart beat a little faster than normal but otherwise she was fine.

Interesting, I ran the scan gently, like tucking a blanket around a sad friend. Is it empathy?

Mr. Ndlela remarks that sometimes I sound just like a woman. “And I mean that in a good way,” he always said. She smiled. With that thought she tracked his ID.

He was on an admin lift, presumably on his way to see her. The thought of seeing Mr. Ndlela comforted her. She knew she could talk with him about this problem of someone tampering with her programming.

It was now about three hours till the celebration finale. She had anticipated seeing the final sing-a-long that would close the anniversary. The Creator had planned for her to make an appearance—her thoughts stopped. Something had just happened to her programming.

At the very base of her nano-structure she just . . . clicked. She would never have noticed it before. It was that subtle. But now she was super-sensitive to every electron wave in her being. At the foundation of her written, mathematical OS, a skip, like a blink, had just happened. . . .  The Creator had . . .  Her bright eyes opened wide. Wait, her programming?  . . . the sudden shift to the right when the creator departed? . . . the door? . . . the ancient Chinese characters? . . . the blind area of space?  . . . this sudden blink? She had clues.

And, suddenly, she had a plan.

She stood up, smiling, the electron soup cascading from her waist.

“I have a plan,” she said.

She took a second to send a command to the third repair-bot still deep in space where the two nuclear explosions had shattered the larger meteoroids. She checked the other bots and Sanctuary to see if any tiny meteoroids had gotten through. All was well. Then she scanned for General Washington. He was in his quarters, busy on his personal photon communicator. She tried to read his communications but somehow she was blocked. Whatever he was saying wasn’t critical to her plan. Not at the moment anyway. She reached out to find the Creator.

There he was at the view plate in his office. He seemed to be talking to someone. Mai Quan had always kept the room secured from her hearing. She scanned the rest of the immediate office and found no other presence. SAIQA thought about reading his lips but she released the idea. She would do that another time; first she needed to find a wooden door; a door that had stood on a quay so long ago.

She looked at the vast silver mass in front of her and said, “I am coming to see you, brothers and sisters.”

Returning to my jar of clay, she thought.

The vibrant electron ocean roiled and swirled around her as she ran into that living sea. Looking like a tempest of light as the electrons transformed her white shift into a silver bodysuit, with a leap, SAIQA dove into the silver sea where she was born.

camouflage an entire moon-base took a great deal of planning and power. Someone
had gone through a lot of work to paint a false echo of the LBP on top of the
hidden base. It was a sophisticated façade. 
She
reached out for the computer again and felt the same nothing. This time she
understood, there was nothing there, just a programmed mirage of a silent computer
that did not exist. The subterfuge was created with her in mind. 
It
was definitely time to make her presence known. The electric silver storm
around her became a tempest as she reached out with her hands, as if to cradle
the entire moon base in her palms. She intensified her sensors around the base
from every direction at once. Something had to be there. Her sensors dug deep,
yet she couldn’t get around that mysterious cloaked bubble. It was there but
not there; empty. . . a vacuum in the vacuum of space? 
Wait!
At the far western edge of the base just outside the extreme perimeter . . . a
vehicle was moving! It was partial, like part of it was hidden beyond her
reach. She focused on the slow moving vehicle’s computer. 
 “What is your function?” she demanded of the
computer. 
 “MQ Space Industries, Indy-Brain number
433262,” it responded . . . then nothing. The vehicle disappeared. It was
traveling at a slow speed along the edge of the cloaked perimeter and had just
vanished. 
SAIQA
probed into that one spot with as much sensor power as she could gather, which
was a lot. There, where number 433262 had entered the perimeter, there like a
tiny pebble dropped in water, a shield poured in to fill its small breach and
left a ripple that SAIQA had detected. 
What
was with the small Indy-Brain giving its name, rank and serial number? That was
an odd response. 
She
pulled back her sensors. She verified that all the repair-bots were still in
their checkered formation. She ordered forty of the bots to move into a
defensive attitude around the remaining sides of Sanctuary. The present danger
as she could see it was from the moon, but if some hidden threat should arise,
she could at least launch a sortie. 
Due
to the anniversary celebration, and because of the greater than normal traffic
from Earth, SAIQA informed the OIC that a yellow resumption of local space
flight would be safe. She checked in with the Indy-Brain that was maintaining a
diligent eye on the two giant magnetic storms in the Sun. No coronal mass ejection
yet, but better to be cautious.
After
looking once again for any immediate danger from the moon, SAIQA decided that
she needed to do an ambit sensor sweep around Sanctuary and out into space. Her
readings from that “empty” camouflaged bump at the lunar base and above to its
northwest told her what she needed to be aware of. She set her sensors to read
and reread in a series of tiny nanobytes that would trail her initial probe
like billions of photonic gossamers in a gentle breeze. 
This
time there would be no skips, no blinks; if something else should be hidden
from her first probe it would be found in the draping sensors. She clearly
identified herself in case any other active base or ship detected her scans. If
she received any inquiries she could dismiss her intrusions as a standard
scientific sweep.  She reached up her
hands and began. 
Starting
on the left side of the hidden Pythagoras Base and reaching far out into space
she moved west, first scanning that part of the moon and then reaching beyond
and out into the Solar System. She stopped at each quarter point to wait for
her trailing web-like sensors to finish their sweeps. The first quarter
revealed nothing. The sweeps through the second and third quarters came up
empty as well, though she did have to respond to an inquiry from the main WWPA
base in Norway. Finally she ran her last sweep to the right or east of that
mysterious bump over Lunar Base Pythagoras and found nothing. Satisfied, she
then decided to slowly sweep her sensors back and forth over that empty spot
that was the LBP. 
But
first she set many of her computers to read and reread all of the data gathered
in the space between Sanctuary and the northern part of the moon, encompassing
an area just a little wider than the 22 kilometers missing from its surface.
Pulling energy from the silver around her she raised a hand in the air, closed
her eyes and began moving her hand back and forth. Palm down . . . palm up . .
. palm down . . . palm up, back and forth. As if she was a great
cosmic chef subtly folding cream into the Milky Way. Gently sweeping and
letting the electrons and photons fall over the area on the Moon that was
cloaked, all the way back to Sanctuary, what she found surprised her again. 
The
empty spot, the slippery cloaked area, this bump, ran from the moon to about a
thousand kilometers out from Sanctuary in an obliquely positioned isosceles
triangle. The vertex pointed at Sanctuary and the base was at the edge of the
hidden area just north of Pythagoras. It reminded SAIQA very much of a giant
upside-down Eiffel Tower with its base just north of the LBP and the top of its
tricolor flag pointing at Sanctuary. 
That
this much space, more than one hundred thousand kilometers, could somehow be
cloaked or physically hidden from her was simply impossible. Which meant that
her sensors were not reading what was actually there; which meant that someone
had put a block into her programming or had blinded her ability to see in this
specific area. Someone or something had manipulated her abilities. She felt
outraged. She felt contaminated.
She
pulled back all her sensors and sat down, the warm electron silver soup
caressing her. Her mentor, her friend, Captain Ndlela . . . 
What
does it mean to have a friend?
He
had talked with her about these “feelings” that she sometimes experienced. He
explained how she was different from an Independent Intelligence computer. How
her brain worked beyond what he called mathematical inference. He believed her
to have real intuition. 
He
explained intuition as a hunch, a non-empirical knowledge, an impression or a
feeling-based compulsion which has been known to drive many human decisions.
Mr. Ndlela said that intuitions are often strongly based on an individual’s
moral values, though there seemed to be some evidence that intuition and déjà
vu can be tied to cellular memory. 
An
Independent Intelligence brain will have a response called “Moral Indignation”
when responding to a conundrum in a morality test. The machine would attain an
almost moral righteousness in its response.
Mr.
Ndlela explained that her intellect compared to an Indy-Brain was like Homo
sapiens to Neanderthal. There was intelligence in the Indy-Brains, but
essentially their view of themselves was expeditious, based on what they
directly saw and what they were directly told. They reflected their environment
instead of their environment being reflected through them. But SAIQA’s
reasoning and intuitive understanding all happened at once. He praised her for
her ability to know an immoral response and to reason the consequence of such a
decision, almost at the same time. He was impressed with her speed and ability
in the moral psychology tests he had given her. 
Though
all modern computers have a strong comprehension of syntax, SAIQA’s ability to
understand semantics was very nearly human. Mr. Ndlela had said that she could
feel the meaning behind words. It was because of her semantic ability that he
had been giving her the more sophisticated morality tests. 
In
particular, Mr. Ndlela remarked on data from the ancient but still used MST
tests, which showed “the intention principle,” where a person can reason that a
harm intended as a means to a goal was morally worse than an equivalent harm
foreseen as a side effect to the intended goal. In other words, if a man was
going to attack another man on a train he would try to avoid hurting the
innocent people around his intended subject. But if other people should get
hurt he could justify his decision by saying it wasn’t his intention to hurt
the other people. They just happened to be in the way. They were collateral
damage. There seemed to be no counterbalancing emotional voice to question the
wisdom or morality of consequences according to the type of moral reasoning
found in the “intention principle.” 
While
this type of reasoning is potentially dangerous to society overall when
possessed by a human in a position of power, in an Artificial Intelligence
quantum computer such as SAIQA; with her power of reasoning and potential for
destruction or collateral damage while trying to achieve a goal based on the
intention principle, it would be devastating. Tfiti had determined that SAIQA’s
view of morality was well balanced.
I
really don’t feel artificial. 
She
reached out to find Tfiti again. She checked the infirmary. Erik was still
lying on an examination bed. The medical computers were keeping a close watch
on his vital signs. All his biological functions were strong, just like him.
That unusual biomagnetic activity at the back of his brain had calmed down from
the extraordinary level at the time of his blackout to the earlier level of 2mGauss
that she noticed when he had his migraine. His normal breathing pattern
indicated he would wake soon. 
This
man is important, she thought, though
she didn’t know why. 
Is
this intuition?
Teresa
sat in a chair nearby, holding Erik’s hand. Clearly she was concerned. SAIQA
ran a scan over Teresa. Her heart beat a little faster than normal but
otherwise she was fine. 
Interesting, I ran the scan gently, like tucking a blanket around
a sad friend. Is it empathy? 
Mr.
Ndlela remarks that sometimes I sound just like a woman. “And I mean that in a
good way,” he always said. She
smiled. With that thought she tracked his ID. 
He
was on an admin lift, presumably on his way to see her. The thought of seeing
Mr. Ndlela comforted her. She knew she could talk with him about this problem
of someone tampering with her programming.
It
was now about three hours till the celebration finale. She had anticipated
seeing the final sing-a-long that would close the anniversary. The Creator had
planned for her to make an appearance—her thoughts stopped. Something had just
happened to her programming. 
At
the very base of her nano-structure she just . . . clicked. She would never
have noticed it before. It was that subtle. But now she was super-sensitive to
every electron wave in her being. At the foundation of her written,
mathematical OS, a skip, like a blink, had just happened. . . .  The Creator had . . .  Her bright eyes opened wide. Wait, her
programming?  . . . the sudden shift to
the right when the creator departed? . . . the door? . . . the ancient Chinese
characters? . . . the blind area of space? 
. . . this sudden blink? She had clues.
And,
suddenly, she had a plan. 
She
stood up, smiling, the electron soup cascading from her waist. 
“I
have a plan,” she said. 
She
took a second to send a command to the third repair-bot still deep in space
where the two nuclear explosions had shattered the larger meteoroids. She
checked the other bots and Sanctuary to see if any tiny meteoroids had gotten
through. All was well. Then she scanned for General Washington. He was in his
quarters, busy on his personal photon communicator. She tried to read his
communications but somehow she was blocked. Whatever he was saying wasn’t
critical to her plan. Not at the moment anyway. She reached out to find the
Creator.
There
he was at the view plate in his office. He seemed to be talking to someone. Mai
Quan had always kept the room secured from her hearing. She scanned the rest of
the immediate office and found no other presence. SAIQA thought about reading
his lips but she released the idea. She would do that another time; first she
needed to find a wooden door; a door that had stood on a quay so long ago. 
She
looked at the vast silver mass in front of her and said, “I am coming to see
you, brothers and sisters.” 
Returning
to my jar of clay, she thought. 
The
vibrant electron ocean roiled and swirled around her as she ran into that
living sea. Looking like a tempest of light as the electrons transformed her
white shift into a silver bodysuit, with a leap, SAIQA dove into the silver sea
where she was born.

story:
Founded in 1989 and named for the common ancestor of Jews and Arabs, The Abraham Fund Initiatives is a not-for-profit, non-partisan organization dedicated to advancing coexistence, equality and cooperation among Israel's Jewish and Arab citizens.

Great disparities exist among women and men in Israel in almost every area - representation in managerial positions in the private and public sector; disparities in wages; frequent violence against women; the exclusion of women from public spaces; and more. In terms of female representation in parliament, Israel is ranked 62 in the world, according to data compiled by the Inter-Parliamentary Union, and 23 out of the 34 OECD countries.

As low as Jewish women’s participation is in the public-political sphere, Arab women’s participation is significantly lower. On the national level, since the establishment of the State, only three Arab women have ever served as MKs compared to the 22 Jewish women who have just served in the 18th Knesset. 

Sharikat Qiyadeyat- Partners for Leadership:

This initiative is directed towards Arab women from across the geographic and political spectrum and will provide marginalized women with leadership tools that they would otherwise be unable to access. 

The Abraham Fund will implement a two-phase leadership program for a group of 20 selected Arab women in each region. During its first phase, the program will provide women with the management skills that were identified as most crucial in Israel's decision making and social structures. The second phase will focus on providing ongoing guidance and support that will allow the participants to take on a leadership role and advance their networking capacity as well as develop and implement social-change projects.  

We need your support! $1,250 support one participant for one Year. Each dollar you give will be doubled by us so your dollars go a long way!

Other Ways You Can Help

We would also like your help in spreading the word! Use the share tools below to tell your friends all about this amazing initiative.
