story:
As Sara Robison, I have published articles and poetry in local newspapers--including The Liberty Tribune and The Kansas City Star. This is my first book. 

About The Book:

When I was diagnosed with breast cancer, 900 women a week were dying of it. Thankfully in 2012, that figure was reduced to 760 women per week. That is still too many! While there are new drugs available, some women with breast cancer still have to take chemo with all its debilitating side effects.

A few months ago, I gave a talk about "Women of Class" and was encouraged to publish the book. It contains my own story plus the stories of 29 anonymous women's experiences while going through breast cancer diagnosis, surgery, treatments, family matters and dealing with depression. In addition to our stories, I have included information that should be of help.

I have posted "Sara's Notes", that includes segments of three other women's stories and "SOS for Caregivers and Loved Ones" at the bottom of this page just before the contribution button.

Even with cancer as a subject, you will find lots of humor in this book because humor gives relief. Heaven knows, we thirty women needed relief as we experienced breast cancer.

Here's How You Can Help

I'm hoping to raise $3,030 with this campaign. The money will be used to cover expenses such as having the book edited, made available on Kindle and Nook, paperback, getting ISBN, copyright and distribution of books,etc. If I raise more than that amount, I will use the extra money for marketing. To contribute go to the bottom of this page and click on the red button that says: Contribute Now.

The Goal:

You can help us reach as many women, diagnosed with breast cancer, and their families as soon as possible. I would love to have this book out before Christmas. However, this is my first book and I don't quite know what to expect. I'm playing it safe by estimating January 2014. Be assured, if it is ready before then, you will receive it earlier.

If we don't reach our goal, we will still publish, but may have to cut back to Kindle and paperbacks or possibly just Kindle.

About the Perks:

By pledging, you will be listed in the back of the book as a "Woman of Class Philanthropist". Plus, I will be providing my original bookmarks that you may want to keep or share with friends. I have three unique designs. One of my designs includes my drawing and story of "A What". I look forward to seeing you on the list...and I know, like all the women I interviewed, you will be at the top of the class!

Other ways you can help:

If you are unable to contribute, you can make lots of noise about this project. Pass it on to your friends, neighbors, relatives and acquaintances via Facebook, Twitter, Email, Youtube, etc. We never know who has been touched by breast cancer... You can also like our Facebook page, "Women of Class Book"--just press the Facebook like button underneath my video. If you are on a blog site, I would appreciate your mention of this book.

Please use the Indiegogo share tools to let other folks know you think they should consider helping with this project. 

Thanks for reading and for your consideration! 

One of the women I interviewed wanted to share the following with you:

Created by the Alton Chapter of Make Today Count at Saint Anthony's, 1983. Special thanks to Saint Anthony's Hospital for reprinting permission.

                   25 Practical Tips For Those Facing Serious Illnesses

When someone is facing an illness, especially a serious illness, we often feel helpless. Here are some practical tips to really help someone facing an illness...from people who have been there...

 1. Don't avoid me. Be the friend...the loved one, you've always been.

 2.Touch me. A simple squeeze of my hand can tell me you still care.

 3. Call to tell me you're bringing my favorite dish and what time you are coming.    Bring food in disposable containers, so I won't have to worry about returns.

 4. Take care of my children for me. I need a little time to be alone with a loved    one. My children may also need a vacation from my illness.

 5. Weep with me when I weep. Laugh with me when I laugh. Don't be afraid to      share this with me.

 6. Take me out for a pleasure trip but know my limitations.

 7. Call for my shopping list and make a "special" delivery to my home.

 8. Call me before you visit, but don't be afraid to visit. I need you. I am lonely.

 9. Help me celebrate holidays (and life!) by decorating my hospital room or          home. Or bring me tiny gifts of flowers or other natural treasures.

10. Help my family. I am sick, but they may be suffering. Offer to come and stay    with me to give my loved ones a break. Invite them out. Take them places.

11. Be creative! Bring me a book of thoughts, taped music, a poster for my wall, cookies to share with my family and friends...an old friend who hasn't been to       see me.

12. Let's talk about it. Maybe I need to talk about my illness. Find out by asking    me: "Do you feel like talking about it?"

13. Don't feel we always have to talk. We can sit quietly together.

14. Can you take me or my children somewhere? I may need transportation to a    treatment...to the store...to a doctor.

15. Help me feel good about my looks. Tell me I look good considering my             illness.  

16. Please include me in decision making. I've been robbed of so many things.     Please don't deny me a chance to make decisions in my family...in my life.

17. Talk to me of the future. Tomorrow, next week, next year. Hope is so            important to me.

18. Bring me a positive attitude. It's catching!

19. What's in the news? Magazines, photos, newspapers and verbal reports        keep me from feeling the world is passing me by.

20. Could you help with cleaning? During my illness, my family and I still face:       dirty clothes, dirty dishes, dirty house.

21. Water my flowers.

22. Just send a card to say, "I care."

23. Pray for me and share your faith with me.

24. Tell me what you'd like to do for me and, when I agree, please do it!

25. Tell me about support groups so I can share with others.

                                                              ###

                                 SOS for Caregivers and Loved Ones

If you have a loved one with breast cancer--you can help by being supportive. This may be especially hard for husbands. As the protector of the family, it may be hard to accept that you have no control over the situation. Living with a women going through breast cancer can be equal to driving your car up Independence Pass, hitting a slick spot and sliding toward the edge.

So what can you do? Listen to what she has to say. Listening is the most important thing you can do. When she shares her feelings, don't be judgmental. No one can control how they feel. Feelings are neither right or wrong--they just are. Be an active listener. One way to do this is to say, "I hear you saying...," and repeat back to her the thoughts she shared with you. Don't think about your response or how you can fix it--JUST LISTEN.

Attend oncologists visits with her whenever possible. It helps her to know that you are in this together. If you are unable to go with her, encourage her to take a friend or a relative. I even had a new customer from the store volunteer to drive me to the plastic surgeon. My husband, Lynn, attended every oncologist visit with me. I felt like we were in this fight together.

Barbara's husband, Tom, said, "Barbara would tell me she could go for chemo treatments by herself. That was unrealistic--the treatments made her too sick. When I couldn't go, my mom or dad went with her."

Tom also suggested keeping a journal and documenting drug treatments.

Another friend, Harold, who lost his wife to breast cancer, had this advice, "Take life one day at a time. Norman Vincent Peale's book, "Have a Great Day", and Billy Graham's book, "One Day at a Time", were very helpful to both of us.

In addition, Harold offered this advice, "Don't pull away from people. If you do, you will feel alienated. People are willing to help, but sometimes they don't know what to do. If you ask them to do something concrete, they will do it. By reaching out to others, it can help them, too."

If your wife or loved one is depressed, encourage her to get help by attending a support group, seeing a counselor, or both. It is hard to always be brave and supportive--you may need counseling, too.

Encourage her in dreams she wants to pursue. Lynn was so supportive in my writing of this book. Working full-time, I could not have accomplished it without his help. For instance, he did most of the evening cooking and cleanup while I wrote.

With breast cancer, the family feel they are facing an insurmountable object--like a large elephant in the living room. At some point, they may come to realize breast cancer poses the question--How do you climb over an elephant? One step at a time.     

                                                         ###

NOTES FROM SARA

The big "C" changed my life. I learned to live life one day at a time and not to put off doing the things I want to do...like writing a book, telling people I love them and savoring each moment as it come. At first, I felt the big "C" was a millstone, but now, it has become a milestone in my life.

The following are excerpts from "Women of Class"...

JAMIE

"I would come home at night and take a pain pill to ease the pain of my breast expanders. One night, I had changed into my pj's and put on a beanie to keep my bald head warm. I was spaced out and talking to my mother on the phone. I saw my cat run by on the wall shelving, as if he was chasing something. I thought, Am I seeing things? Suddenly, something hit the TV and landed in my lap. It was alive!"

Jamie screamed, threw the phone and jumped up. All her mother heard was screaming. She couldn't get the phone to disconnect, so ran to the next-door neighbors and dialed 911. Then she called Jamie's next-door neighbor and went racing over to Jamie's house. Jamie was outside having hysterics by this time. A squirrel had landed in her lap. Apparently, it had come down through the chimney. Friends came in and tried to catch it and they all laughed--even the police laughed.

ELIZABETH

"I thought I was going for some R&R or something. I took books to read and cards to play."

With a grin she went on, "I had packed like I was going to the South Seas. The doctor told me I would be in the hospital five to seven days, so i had seven lovely gowns to wear. One was a Mickey Mouse--I thought I'd have some fun with this."

From my experience with the same surgery, I can tell you Elizabeth didn't get to use any of those gowns in the hospital. In addition, she didn't have much fun either.

BARBARA

Barbara showed those pretty dimples when she recalled an incident at the doctor's office.

"I hate  to get on the scales to get weighed. They write down, 'with shoes,' and I told them they need to add, 'with prosthesis.' I've threatened to take it off before they weigh me. I have the new type of prosthesis that you attach to your skin. It's heavy and you can almost almost shimmy in it; it bounces just like a real breast.

She was smiling now with all that little girl exuberance. "I feel like a drag queen at night because I take off my wig and I take off my breast. I also have a device to hook the 'chemo' up to--it's called a Hickman (port). What you see now is not what you get."    

                                                               ###

10. Help my family. I am sick, but they may be suffering. Offer to come and stay    with me to give my loved ones a break. Invite them out. Take them places.
11. Be creative! Bring me a book of thoughts, taped music, a poster for my wall, cookies to share with my family and friends...an old friend who hasn't been to       see me.
12. Let's talk about it. Maybe I need to talk about my illness. Find out by asking    me: "Do you feel like talking about it?"
13. Don't feel we always have to talk. We can sit quietly together.
14. Can you take me or my children somewhere? I may need transportation to a    treatment...to the store...to a doctor.
15. Help me feel good about my looks. Tell me I look good considering my             illness.  
16. Please include me in decision making. I've been robbed of so many things.     Please don't deny me a chance to make decisions in my family...in my life.
17. Talk to me of the future. Tomorrow, next week, next year. Hope is so            important to me.
18. Bring me a positive attitude. It's catching!
19. What's in the news? Magazines, photos, newspapers and verbal reports        keep me from feeling the world is passing me by.
20. Could you help with cleaning? During my illness, my family and I still face:       dirty clothes, dirty dishes, dirty house.
21. Water my flowers.
22. Just send a card to say, "I care."
23. Pray for me and share your faith with me.
24. Tell me what you'd like to do for me and, when I agree, please do it!
25. Tell me about support groups so I can share with others.
                                                              ###
                                 SOS for Caregivers and Loved Ones
If you have a loved one with breast cancer--you can help by being supportive. This may be especially hard for husbands. As the protector of the family, it may be hard to accept that you have no control over the situation. Living with a women going through breast cancer can be equal to driving your car up Independence Pass, hitting a slick spot and sliding toward the edge.
So what can you do? Listen to what she has to say. Listening is the most important thing you can do. When she shares her feelings, don't be judgmental. No one can control how they feel. Feelings are neither right or wrong--they just are. Be an active listener. One way to do this is to say, "I hear you saying...," and repeat back to her the thoughts she shared with you. Don't think about your response or how you can fix it--JUST LISTEN.
Attend oncologists visits with her whenever possible. It helps her to know that you are in this together. If you are unable to go with her, encourage her to take a friend or a relative. I even had a new customer from the store volunteer to drive me to the plastic surgeon. My husband, Lynn, attended every oncologist visit with me. I felt like we were in this fight together.
Barbara's husband, Tom, said, "Barbara would tell me she could go for chemo treatments by herself. That was unrealistic--the treatments made her too sick. When I couldn't go, my mom or dad went with her."
Tom also suggested keeping a journal and documenting drug treatments.
Another friend, Harold, who lost his wife to breast cancer, had this advice, "Take life one day at a time. Norman Vincent Peale's book, "Have a Great Day", and Billy Graham's book, "One Day at a Time", were very helpful to both of us.
In addition, Harold offered this advice, "Don't pull away from people. If you do, you will feel alienated. People are willing to help, but sometimes they don't know what to do. If you ask them to do something concrete, they will do it. By reaching out to others, it can help them, too."
If your wife or loved one is depressed, encourage her to get help by attending a support group, seeing a counselor, or both. It is hard to always be brave and supportive--you may need counseling, too.
Encourage her in dreams she wants to pursue. Lynn was so supportive in my writing of this book. Working full-time, I could not have accomplished it without his help. For instance, he did most of the evening cooking and cleanup while I wrote.
With breast cancer, the family feel they are facing an insurmountable object--like a large elephant in the living room. At some point, they may come to realize breast cancer poses the question--How do you climb over an elephant? One step at a time.     
                                                         ###
NOTES FROM SARA
The big "C" changed my life. I learned to live life one day at a time and not to put off doing the things I want to do...like writing a book, telling people I love them and savoring each moment as it come. At first, I felt the big "C" was a millstone, but now, it has become a milestone in my life.
The following are excerpts from "Women of Class"...
JAMIE
"I would come home at night and take a pain pill to ease the pain of my breast expanders. One night, I had changed into my pj's and put on a beanie to keep my bald head warm. I was spaced out and talking to my mother on the phone. I saw my cat run by on the wall shelving, as if he was chasing something. I thought, Am I seeing things? Suddenly, something hit the TV and landed in my lap. It was alive!"
Jamie screamed, threw the phone and jumped up. All her mother heard was screaming. She couldn't get the phone to disconnect, so ran to the next-door neighbors and dialed 911. Then she called Jamie's next-door neighbor and went racing over to Jamie's house. Jamie was outside having hysterics by this time. A squirrel had landed in her lap. Apparently, it had come down through the chimney. Friends came in and tried to catch it and they all laughed--even the police laughed.
ELIZABETH
"I thought I was going for some R&R or something. I took books to read and cards to play."
With a grin she went on, "I had packed like I was going to the South Seas. The doctor told me I would be in the hospital five to seven days, so i had seven lovely gowns to wear. One was a Mickey Mouse--I thought I'd have some fun with this."
From my experience with the same surgery, I can tell you Elizabeth didn't get to use any of those gowns in the hospital. In addition, she didn't have much fun either.
BARBARA
Barbara showed those pretty dimples when she recalled an incident at the doctor's office.
"I hate  to get on the scales to get weighed. They write down, 'with shoes,' and I told them they need to add, 'with prosthesis.' I've threatened to take it off before they weigh me. I have the new type of prosthesis that you attach to your skin. It's heavy and you can almost almost shimmy in it; it bounces just like a real breast.
She was smiling now with all that little girl exuberance. "I feel like a drag queen at night because I take off my wig and I take off my breast. I also have a device to hook the 'chemo' up to--it's called a Hickman (port). What you see now is not what you get."    
                                                               ###

story:
If you're arriving at this page for the very first time, WELCOME! Scroll down to the headline, "Call a Truce on the Effects of Sexual Abuse."

...

As you may know, Not Marked reached 100% of its funding on Thursday, September 5th, twenty days before the end of the campaign. Amazing! The next phase of the project is stretch goals.

What are stretch goals?

Stretch goals expand the campaign and help get the book into more hands. The cool thing for you (if you're a backer) is that stretch goals, if met, simply add to your rewards. For instance, if I reach the $25,000 goal, every single backer will receive an audio book.

With that in mind, I’m excited to announce the crazy-audacious stretch goals for Not Marked. I’m beyond surprised and grateful for the support that’s come in so far. Reading your comments has really blessed me.

As I’m writing this, Not Marked is with my substantive editor. I spent the weekend tweaking and editing it before I sent it her way.

Here's me chatting about the stretch goals:



Here are our stretch goals for Not Marked.

We made it to $15,000! All backers now have the opportunity to ask a question about sexual abuse. Hooray!

We made it to $17,000! All backers will have a free webinar. Date: Monday, September 30th, 7:00 PM CST.

We made it to $19,000. All backers will receive an E-study guide for the book. Estimated delivery, March 2014.

We made it to $21,000! I'll begin work on the bonus chapter, to be included in the book's release.

Look for an upcoming webinar about learning to create boundaries with bestselling author Allison Bottke. Webinar scheduled Wednesday October 9th, 7:00 PM CST.

This has funded! Now, every single backer will receive the audio recording, ready for your listening pleasure. (Hint: Maybe I can even convince my hubby to read his part!)

Call a truce on the effects of sexual abuse.

I didn't do this. For far too many years. I resigned myself to let the rapes from the past mess with my head and heart. Flashbacks invaded my sleep. I startled far too easily. Sex within marriage became scary and complicated. I often wondered if I'd ever be normal. I even disconnected from those I loved the most.

The mark that sexual abuse gave me felt indelible, permanently inked with a Sharpie pen. And no matter of scrubbing erased it. (Have you ever felt this way?)

The problem was, I felt that I should be "over" it (and well-meaning people said those same things to me.) After all, I became a Christian, and I heard all those sermons about everything being made brand spanking new. I believed that when I met Jesus, all those scars and marks and fears would instantly leave.

But they didn't erase.

The pathway to healing came when I realized I needed to face the past again, to choose to heal for my sake and for the sake of those who loved me. I desperately needed freedom. Have you had this same ache?

You are not alone.

Here's my story from my memoir, Thin Places (Zondervan).


This is how I looked when the neighborhood teenagers raped me:

Your Abuse Hurts Others Too

I wish I could say that sexual abuse only affected the little girl in that picture, but the truth is, other people are hurt because we've been hurt. It's so not fair, but it's reality. 

That's why I felt it extremely important to add Patrick's voice to this project. After every chapter, he shares his perspective as the spouse of a victim, how he coped, what he did right and wrong, and how we healed together. Here's what Patrick has to say:


I wrote Not Marked for those who have been exploited, but I also wrote it for those who want to help the person in your life who can't seem to get beyond that painful memory.

Articles Around the Web

I have not been silent about this journey--I just haven't published an entire book about my healing process--yet.

I've written about my struggle in marriage in this viral post, "The Sexy Wife I Can't Be." in A Deeper Church

Patrick and I also wrote a post for Christianity Today (Today's Christian Woman) titled "Opening the Door to Healing."

And I stuck up for victims in the Her.meneutics post, "I'm Sick of Hearing of Your Smoking Hot Wife." 

On my website, I've exposed sexual abuse in the Amish community in "Bonnets, Buggies and Sexual Abuse."

And recently, I read a letter to those boys who molested me:


I wrote Not Marked because it's the book I needed to read (and I believe it's a book many need to read).

I did find solace in a counseling-based book, but since it hadn't been written from an abuse-victim's perspective, I had a hard time believing the tools shared would help. I asked for a lot of prayer. I went to counseling. I read anything that pertained to healing from sexual abuse, but to be honest, I often felt utterly alone. I believed no one understood. I kept wanting to GET OVER IT, but couldn't.

(Artist's rendering)

Not Marked is the book I was created to write. It's tearing back the curtain from my healing journey--the good, the bad, the frustrating, the victorious. It explores the multifaceted way we get well--spiritually, emotionally, physically, mentally. It gives practical guidance, mixed with story and hope.

I sit here writing this Indiegogo page as an unmarked girl, one who has healed so beautifully from the past that many don't even know I walked that trail of tears.

And yet, I still ache...not as much for me and that abused little girl, but for YOU.

I want to see you find raucous, wild healing, to be set free from what has marked you. I want you to hold this book in your hands, read the message of hope, and then start down your own freedom path.

Read how others have responded to Mary's story of healing:

  • "It amazes me how you, someone I've never met and probably never will on this earth, could in so many ways offer such insight to me of
    myself--mainly through God giving you the ability to make yourself so
    transparent and gifting you with the talent of expressing it in words."     Kerstin
  • "Thanks again for your authenticity. It's refreshing to see and read, resonating with life in a fallen world, where God's glory shines brightest in our weakness and darkness." Paul
  • "I have been wounded by the same kind of teachings about marital intimacy and pleasing our husbands. Your testimony gave me 'permission' to still be broken - not an excuse, not justification to withhold myself...just the grace to not be 'sexy wife.'" Christine
  • "On so many areas of my life Mary is the brave voice that spoke out loud for all to hear what I can't even verbalize to myself." Deborah
  • "What makes it beautiful is the courage Mary displays by opening up her life for all to see, all the painful, awful things that happened to her, the ways it still affects her now, and how she's found, and is finding, freedom." Chuck
  • "I just asked my husband to read [about being marked], and it provided a springboard for much needed conversation. I kept saying to him, 'This is me; this is me.' He is reading it, and our conversations after 20 years of marriage have reached a whole new depth." Kathleen
  • "I was deeply touched that you normalize this journey and give hope.  This hope will touch generations. My family is directly impacted by your book. I sat down with it feeling very discouraged. Like I was losing the battle for intimacy - physical & emotional - (you know those days where everything triggers you?) but it gave me courage in my journey which infused grace into the interactions with my family for the rest of the day." Timi

How You Can Help:

I've already written Not Marked. Like I've done with my 15 other traditionally published books, I've shopped Not Marked to publishers. But the book is too risky, too raw, and they're afraid to publish it. I totally get that. But I believe in the book's hopeful message, so I'm taking on the risk myself, and asking if you'd be willing to shoulder some of it alongside me.

Publishing a book takes money if you want to do it right. And this book deserves to be handled with excellence. The money from this Indiegogo campaign does NOT go into my purse. It will go into the pockets of:

  • Editors
  • Designers
  • Marketers
  • Formatters
  • and a Book Printer

Thanks for helping me shed light on this dark, dark secret. Your generosity will help set people free.

As a thank you for your help, I've provided many different types of backing levels with books, teaching, and speaking as an incentive. I even ask for YOUR story as one of the backing levels. 

Stuff You Get:

Most of the levels are self-explanatory, but here are a few highlights: 

These six audio sessions will help you get past your past. I tell my story accompanied by teaching and biblical truth. All six messages ask you life-changing questions and offer hope for the future. Read more about the audio retreat here.

Live Uncaged started as a compilation of all my posts on healing from the past. That morphed into a real, live book--95 pages of wisdom, hard won, ripped from the headlines of my life. It’s my great, big wish that you’d find soaring healing, deep freedom, and the uncaged life you've longed for. Find out more about Live Uncaged here.

Watching the tree limbs keeps resilient nine-year-old Mara Weatherall from the pain of General’s daily attacks–attacks he warns her to keep secret, or else. In the small world of 1979 Burl, Texas, all Mara really has are the tree limbs, a lumbering Aunt Elma, her boyfriend Officer Gus, the bully General, and her new best friend Camilla who rhymes maddening snatches of truth. This novel displays the healing journey from sexual abuse in story form. Read more about Watching the Tree Limbs here.

God says “I love you” in many ways, some of which are hard to hear. Like every teenager, Maranatha tries to sort out the confusing layers of love–of friends, of family, of suitors, and, desperately, of God. She struggles to find herself before the darkness of the past pulls her back to the shadow of the girl she used to be in this moving follow-up to the critically praised Watching the Tree Limbs. Read more about Wishing on Dandelions here.

This Isn't My First Rodeo:

Publishing is a difficult journey, no matter how you pursue it. Having a tribe of people backing this sensitive project will not only bolster Not Marked's success, but it also will encourage me in this crazy writing adventure.

It's been a long journey, starting with my first published book in 2005.

I've written dozens of books with publishers like Thomas Nelson, Zondervan, Tyndale, NavPress and Harvest House Publishers.

I also speak around the world about living an uncaged life. If you'd like to find out more about me, visit my website. Find me on Facebook here. Follow me on Twitter here. Visit me on Google+ here. And link with me at Linked In here.

Thank you for believing in the message of Not Marked so that others (and maybe even you) can be set free from the past and live an uncaged, joyful life today.

story:
Mark Twain said, “Truth is stranger than fiction, but it is because fiction is obliged to stick to possibilities; Truth isn't.”   

That nicely sums up The Snipe Hunter.  It is a true story which ranges well beyond possibilities that would make a believable novel. I know all too well that this narrative is not fiction.  I lived it.  

Mine is the story of a covert operation to support the Afghanistan mujahedeen in the late 1980s. The larger history of this period was told in George Crile’s book “Charlie Wilson’s War”.  However, The Snipe Hunter is my personal first hand account of how the combination of reactionary foreign policy, political expediency, blind ambition, ignorance and greed impacted the lives of the people involved. People who, for reasons ranging from patriotism to avarice, were caught up in an operation that would be unbelievable if it were fiction. The story spans the globe, from the Americas to Southeast Asia to the Middle-East and Europe.  It has all the elements of a novel, high sea adventure, international finance, drug smuggling, manhunts, malfeasance, rogue ops and two wars.  It’s an inside look at how covert operations are conceptualized and mounted and it examines the criminal justice system from the inside as well as the outside. 

At the same time it’s the story of how my wife Sharon and I started a new life in Israel with no money or connections and developed an underwater photography business that grew, over thirteen years into a full service underwater equipment supply, design, and manufacturing company. The company served the diving industry in three countries, many institutions, universities, businesses, and the Israeli defense forces.

More importantly, it’s the story of how my life was profoundly changed by my misconceptions of ethical principles like – greater good, governmental authority, right and wrong, self interest, loyalty, ends justifying means, and serving country. It recounts my 13 years living in Israel while on the most wanted list, the U.S. Marshall’s world wide hunt for me that culminated in my arrest and extradition, and the five years I spent in the criminal justice system.

After I was released from supervision in 2010, I felt that keeping silent for more than 23 years was enough; it was time to tell my story of this covert operation.  At its inception, I thought our goal was to support the Afghanistan Mujahedeen’s fight against Russian occupation but I  watched as it morphed into a drug smuggle that left me “holding the bag”.  It’s a story that I’ve never told to anyone until now.

For the last ten years I’ve been encouraged by everyone close to me –family, friends, lawyers, colleagues, almost everyone who knows me – to write this book. It marked a turning point in my life more profound than any mid-life crisis.  It changed not only what I thought I knew about myself, but what I thought I knew about my country.   Those closest to me think it might be cathartic to get the story out into the open; let people know what happened, why it happened, and who was behind it.  People outside my inner circle have suggested that there is a larger audience of those that want the truth to be told about things that happen in the dark corners of government.

Current State of the Project:
I've been working on this project for the past 18 months. I have outlined the book and completed the basic research and documentation to substantiate my recollection of the events.  I’ve collected thousands of pages of documents, legal filings, briefs, transcripts and affidavits.  Now I feel it is imperative to interview the many government agents, crew members, U.S. Marshals, ship brokers, and peripheral players involved, so that all sides of the story can be told accurately and fully. After completing these interviews, I will be able to finish the manuscript so it can be edited and put it into final form – press ready and suitable for submission to potential agents and publishers.  The final draft will be formatted for print-on-demand publication and converted into eBook formats (.epud, .pdb, ibooks, Kindle, .pdf, etc.) for on-line distribution.

Why this Campaign:
Being arrested at the age of 65 and losing everything that my beautiful wife and I had been able to build has left us both old and poor.  In order to finish this project I need your help in raising the money required to conduct the interviews, finish the manuscript, edit it, and format it for both print and e-book publishing.     

Use of funds:
Sharon and I plan to spend June and July 2013 traveling cross-country in an RV.  We will start in Miami, Florida. and work our way north and west across the country conducting the aforementioned interviews along the way.  Our trip will terminate in Portland, Oregon near the end of July. This will be far more economical than air travel and hotel expenses and will allow greater flexibility in scheduling.  It will also allow us to transcribe recordings and continue the writing process while still on the road.  The trip will take about 60 days and cover nearly 5,000 miles.

We need to raise $10,500 to pay for our travel and living expenses while conducting the interviews and completing the manuscript, editing, layout of the final draft, fulfillment and promotional printing and eBook conversion and distribution. 

All funds received from this campaign will be used to complete the book and get it published. Funds in excess of my goal will be used for promotion and toward writing a screenplay and movie treatment of the book. In the event that the goal is not reached, I will persevere.  In other words, not raising the entire amount won’t be a show-stopper, I’ll get as far as possible on what I have; I am obliged to bring this story to light.  I truly believe that it is something that I need to do for myself, and for my family.   My wife and children stood by me throughout the entire ordeal, and that kind of loyalty and devotion is something I found to be very rare. Finally, I am motivated by whatever good can come from this memoir as a cautionary tale.

It’s my hope and belief that this campaign will reach its goal; however, regardless of the outcome I will persist with this book through its completion and publication. Telling this story in its entirety has become the central focus of my life.  As I witness the continuing erosion of the fundamental right to “Life, Liberty and the Pursuit of Happiness” that was so clearly expressed in the Declaration of Independence, I mourn the demise of the United States of America that I was taught to believe in and love and that I, in my own way, helped bring to its current state.  I see this book as my way to help undo at least part of the damage, and to deter others from the kind of misguided actions that I became involved in. 

Perks for Contributors:
For your contribution in support of this campaign there are a number of perks offered as a way of showing my gratitude for your backing.  These incentives range from PDF downloads of the manuscript and eBooks, to paperback and Trade Edition books, to fine art prints of the cover art suitable for framing. There is also an opportunity for you to become an advance-reader, or even an associate editor, on this project. All contributors will also receive our e-mail newsletter detailing our progress across the country and updates of the writing process.  Please be sure to check out these perks, they’re my way of saying thank you.

Other Ways You Can Help:
Even if you can't contribute, you can help by spreading the word about my campaign.
Obviously, if you are a literary agent, editor, movie agent, producer, promoter, or know someone who is, I would welcome your input, advice or proposal. You can contact me by email at sid@sidneymlewis.com.
story_txt:
Mark Twain said, “Truth is stranger than fiction, but it is because fiction is obliged to stick to possibilities; Truth isn't.”   
That nicely sums up The Snipe Hunter.  It is a true story which ranges well beyond possibilities that would make a believable novel. I know all too well that this narrative is not fiction.  I lived it.  
Mine is the story of a covert operation to support the Afghanistan mujahedeen in the late 1980s. The larger history of this period was told in George Crile’s book “Charlie Wilson’s War”.  However, The Snipe Hunter is my personal first hand account of how the combination of reactionary foreign policy, political expediency, blind ambition, ignorance and greed impacted the lives of the people involved. People who, for reasons ranging from patriotism to avarice, were caught up in an operation that would be unbelievable if it were fiction. The story spans the globe, from the Americas to Southeast Asia to the Middle-East and Europe.  It has all the elements of a novel, high sea adventure, international finance, drug smuggling, manhunts, malfeasance, rogue ops and two wars.  It’s an inside look at how covert operations are conceptualized and mounted and it examines the criminal justice system from the inside as well as the outside.  
At the same time it’s the story of how my wife Sharon and I started a new life in Israel with no money or connections and developed an underwater photography business that grew, over thirteen years into a full service underwater equipment supply, design, and manufacturing company. The company served the diving industry in three countries, many institutions, universities, businesses, and the Israeli defense forces. 
More importantly, it’s the story of how my life was profoundly changed by my misconceptions of ethical principles like – greater good, governmental authority, right and wrong, self interest, loyalty, ends justifying means, and serving country. It recounts my 13 years living in Israel while on the most wanted list, the U.S. Marshall’s world wide hunt for me that culminated in my arrest and extradition, and the five years I spent in the criminal justice system. 
After I was released from supervision in 2010, I felt that keeping silent for more than 23 years was enough; it was time to tell my story of this covert operation.  At its inception, I thought our goal was to support the Afghanistan Mujahedeen’s fight against Russian occupation but I  watched as it morphed into a drug smuggle that left me “holding the bag”.  It’s a story that I’ve never told to anyone until now.

story:
A Kingdom in Peril...

After closing the rift between Earth and Galadir, Seth Alkirk disappears, leaving the world of Galadir in a troubled state. The remnants of the Findoor army, led by Malia, flee into the west after the dark wizard Grian usurps the throne of her kingdom.
 
Grian is the most dangerous threat the people of Galadir have ever faced. To the west, he invades a neighboring kingdom with a massive army of undead. Narshuks to the south are dying of a disease unleashed by Grian. Wizards to the east struggle against his wraiths to hold on to their stronghold and the libraries within.
 
When Seth reappears, everyone turns to him for salvation. With the weight of an entire world yet again on his shoulders, Seth hatches a plan to show Galadir that they can fight for themselves.
 
Seth doesn't know his evil nemesis has finally found what he's been looking for. As Grian prepares for his final assault on the east to capture what he seeks, all of Galadir confronts him, brought together by a mysterious force. But is it enough? Alliances will be broken, new friendships made, old ones rekindled, and nobody will ever be the same. The battle for Galadir has begun.

The Epic Conclusion to The Time Weaver Chronicles

My name is Thomas A. Knight, and I'm an independent fantasy author. I've been writing novels for almost three years, and writing for fantasy games and campaigns for over twenty. I've published two novels, and this campaign will help fund the editing, publishing and advertising of the third and final novel in The Time Weaver Chronicles.

The launches for my books in the past have been low-key and somewhat quiet because I'm independant, and lack the funding and impact that the big publishers have. For me, getting some funding to help with the launch of my third book will make all the difference in the world.

It's my hope, that with some carefully selected advertising, and the right people helping me out, I can launch my third book onto the bestseller lists, and maybe even take my first two books with it!

What people are saying about The Time Weaver Chronicles...

“I absolutely love The Time Weaver Chronicles. The story is so fascinating, well written, and while it has a lot of fantasy elements that I know and love, it also has new and unique elements that make it even more interesting.” - Megan Monell, Love, Literature, Art, and Reason

"I was caught up in this book from the moment I started reading it. It was so full of action, adventure, magic, mystery, evil, and a twist of romance that I couldn't help but keep reading." - Angela, Angels are Kids and Furkids

“It starts good. I enjoyed it a lot. And as you read on, it gets better. And better.” - Will Knight, Bibliophilia, Please

“Thomas A. Knight's, The Time Weaver is epic in every way. The world building is stunning and detailed, full of scary creatures, monumental landscapes and wonderful characters.” - Sallie Lundy-Frommer, Author, Yesterday's Daughter

What I Need & What You Get

$5,000 is a big goal, right? Not really. Advertising is expensive, especially the kind that will get my books noticed. That's where the bulk of my funding will go.

I'm offering some exclusive items as incentives too! Desktop wallpapers designed by my very talented wife, eBooks, paperbacks, and even hardcovers of all three books. Also, don't miss out on the chance to pick up a beautiful poster-sized print of the map for my world, Galadir.

But hey, what's a campaign without a little fun?

Magic in my world is separated into eight elements: fire, water, earth, air, life, death, time and shadow. Pick one of these, grab the perk for your element, and see which one is the strongest at the end of the campaign. Every person in the winning element will receive a special gift from me: a full-color, custom designed bookmark that matches your element. This will be the only time this particular bookmark will be available, so drum up support for your element, and grab a piece of history.

But wait, there's more!

If I reach my goal, in order to show my appreciation, the single person who brings the most people to my campaign through referrals will receive a $250 Amazon Gift card as a thank you gift.

Even if I don't reach my goal, every penny will count. I'll stretch every dollar to its limit in order to reach my goals for this launch. I'm very excited about it, and feel that this is my best book yet.

The Impact

Books have always had a cultural significance to our world, and fantasy books are no different. Tolkein, Donaldson, Martin, Sanderson, and so many other wonderful authors have taken people into their worlds and enriched their lives with exciting adventures, vivid landscapes, and unique characters. By supporting me and my books, you'll be helping to bring a new world, and new adventures to people everywhere.

My past book launches have landed both of my books on Amazon Bestseller lists. The Time Weaver has been on the Epic Fantasy and Science Fiction Adventure lists a number of times, and Legacy has made it onto the Science Fiction Time Travel bestseller list. With an advertising budget this time, I plan on hitting more than just the Amazon bestseller lists.

Of course, it's not all about me. I have always supported the non-profit charity, Reglue, with a portion of my royalties, and my third book will be no different. $0.50 from every eBook, and $1.00 from every paperback sold are donated to Reglue to help offset their operating costs. By getting the word out, and reaching a broader audience with my launch, I can sell more, and give more to this very worthy cause.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute to my campaign, you can still help! If you are on Facebook or Twitter or G+, make a post linking to my campaign to help spread the word. It costs you nothing, and helps me reach people I would not otherwise reach. Indiegogo makes this super-easy as well. With the sharing tools on the main campaign page, spreading the word is a button-click away.

Other ways you can help me out:

  • Make a blog post about me, my books, or my campaign.
  • Contact me for a guest post on your blog.
  • Post about my campaign on a message forum you frequent.
  • Submit my campaign to Reddit or Stumbleupon (or other social bookmarking sites).
  • Tell your friends, spouse, kids, coworkers, role-playing groups, etc.

Help others learn about a great new fantasy world, and enrich their lives with reading!

Shipping Information

Most perks will ship when the campaign is complete or when the items are ready, with the following exceptions:

  • Copies of Reprisal will be shipped when editing is complete. (Est. December, 2013.)
  • Hard-cover copies of all books will be shipped when they are ready. (Est. December, 2013.)
  • If you select a perk that includes a physical copy of Reprisal, I will ship all of your perks together to save on shipping costs. If you want your stuff sooner, you'll have to help me out with the extra shipping cost.
  • I have worked the cost of shipping into the price of the perk. I'm not asking for extra money for international shipping, but it's appreciated. Shipping is expensive.
  • If there will be delays on shipping any of your items, I'll email you and let you know.

story:
CRITpaper is a start-up periodical created by a small group of smart, talented and ambitious budding art critics in collaboration with art and design students to establish a much-needed site for discussion and coverage of contemporary art in and beyond Halifax, Nova Scotia.

Our Story

In September 2012, a small group of young, dedicated students who are passionately opinionated about art & culture began to discuss the logistics of creating a publication that would serve as a site for critical reviews and essays; after two solid months of hard work, our first issue was released and has so far received diverse and stimulating content from contributors all around the world and has in turn garnered a wide-reaching readership.

We have since produced two 24-page issues with a run of 2000 copies, funded at first by the Student Union of Nova Scotia College of Art & Design University and generous contributions from supporters in our local community. However, since our highly valued former funders can no longer consistently provide for us, we are now turning to you, Internet, for sustenance. We are calling on you to give us the means to print four more issues in 2013 so we can keep alive the critical community discourse we have worked so hard to generate.

Each and every one of our contributors, editors and designers has toiled to facilitate this publication in spite of no pay since our passion, dedication and faith in this project’s potential run deep. Please help us achieve our goal of $10,000 so that the costs of producing CRITpaper can be covered for the rest of 2013, lifting a heavy cost burden from our staff whom have paid a large portion of printing costs out of their own pockets.

What We Need & What You Get

  • Each issue of CRIT has 2000 copies and printed and costs roughly $750 (taxes in). It’s not a lot of money, but for a small group of individuals it is a hefty sum! If we reach our goal we will have enough money to sustain the printing for a year, provide our contributors with a humble honorarium AND have enough to send our members to review a few key exhibitions across North America!
  • As a testament to our appreciation for your support, we will eternalize our gratitude to you in print, in the credits of our upcoming issue (that’s like getting your donation acknowledged by a name plaque on a park bench!) if you kindly send $100 or more. Got a business? Wanna advertise with us? In return for your generosity, we’ll grant you free advertising space on the last outer page of the issue
  • AND if your immense generosity compels you to fully fund the printing of a single issue, you will receive a lifetime subscription to the paper via mail, major recognition in the next issue, and, no doubt, our eternal love and gratitude.
  • If we do not reach our goal, we will still use the funds we do receive to cover the coming third and fourth issues as they come to fruition.

The Impact

Our first two papers had contributers from across the globe, were widely celebrated in the art community and have been sent to our peers across Canada due to demand. Help support this exciting project, bringing stimulating coverage and discourse of art to our hungry readers!

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you can’t contribute, no sweat! Check out our website http://critpaper.com/ or like us on Facebook https://www.facebook.com/CRITpaper and/or share our page on Indiegogo!

story:
Beginnings

Panda Bear’s Paint Box had a hard mint cover with an illustrated silver spine. The word PAINTBOX was printed as a dripping rainbow, all in caps arching above a pensive young bear. Panda was reclining a little, astride a blue tray of watercolor paints. He would soon discover what the primary colors were and find himself covered in them in his quest to fill white pages with his ideas.

My literacy began in color.

Almost thirty years later I find myself working as both a visual artist and poet developing the manuscript for my first chapbook entitled Indigo Season. The Banff Centre for Arts and Culture, has recognized the promise of this work, and as a globally respected incubator for cultural creatives, they have accepted my application for a week-long mini retreat residency in Alberta, Canada.

 

Inspiring Creativity

The Banff Centre for Arts and Culture invites exceptional artists and leaders from around the world to create and perform new works of art and share skills and knowledge in an interdisciplinary environment. This September 9th -15th, the Literary Arts Program has invited me to attend Writing with Style – an international workshop for poets. Will you help me to raise funds necessary to bring my work to the attention of a global audience? This is a prestigious workshop experience that will afford me the opportunity to get an international perspective on my poetry collection in progress, Indigo Season. Your donation will allow this text to take its place on a broader stage, such that readers outside of queer communities and communities of color can learn from my work. Your artistic philanthropy is an act of interdependence, wherein you fund cultural creatives with the skill and passion to design a brighter zeitgeist with their words and materials.

 

Asking for your Support

Writing with Style is an intensive week-long residency program offering sophisticated instruction to selected writers over a carefully designed one-week period. The retreat residency will fill a professional void for me as a Queer writer of color looking to reach and dialogue with mainstream audiences globally. I need to raise as much as I can toward my goal of $2000 by July 19th to cover travel expenses, as well as tuition and room and board. Please check out indiegogo.com/writingwithstyle to donate. Thank you so much!!

All funds donated to this effort will go toward expenses listed below:

Tuition for this workshop is $425

Room and board for 8 days is $725

Roundtrip flight to Calgary International Airport from SFO est. $550

Ground transportation to and from The Banff Centre (located in the mountains of Banff National Park) $130

Grand Total $1830

 

I am writing to ask for your support in achieving this goal. I am currently working to complete my BFA at the California College of the Arts.  My income consists of unsubsidized student loans, federal workstudy wages during the Fall and Spring semesters and freelance videography and editing work.  Like many, I have monthly expenses that regularly exceed my income such that I am unable to set aside funds toward this effort. It is only with your support that I will be able to participate in this amazing opportunity.

 

Beyond Dollars and Cents

If you cannot donate this time around, not to worry, you can still show your support by forwarding this call far and wide (and use indiegogo share tools too). I appreciate you!

 

Bio

Indira Allegra is a writer and interdisciplinary artist representing poetry through performance, video and fiber arts. Her experimental video poem, Blue Covers, has screened nationally and internationally. Indira has contributed work to Cherokee Writers From the Flint Hills of Oklahoma: An Anthology and Sovereign Erotics: A Collection of Two-Spirit Literature, winner of the Silver Medal from the Independent Publisher Book Awards and a finalist for both the Lambda Literary Award and ForeWord Book of the Year Award. She has published work in Konch Magazine, Chicken Skin and Impossible Trees, an Intersection for the Arts writer's lab anthology, as well as Rivets Literary Magazine, Wordgathering Journal of Disability Poetry and Make/Shift Magazine.

Indira is currently co-director for Artists Against Rape and a former member of the artistic core of Sins Invalid. She has worked with Intersection for the Arts, Geneva Car Barn and Powerhouse and proj-ectPRO:JECT to teach digital storytelling and poetry workshops. Indira is a 2012 Lambda Literary Fellow and a Voices Of Nations Arts Alum. She is currently working on her first collection of poems entitled Indigo Season.

Beginnings
Panda Bear’s Paint Box had a hard mint cover with an illustrated silver spine. The word PAINTBOX was printed as a dripping rainbow, all in caps arching above a pensive young bear. Panda was reclining a little, astride a blue tray of watercolor paints. He would soon discover what the primary colors were and find himself covered in them in his quest to fill white pages with his ideas.
My literacy began in color.
Almost thirty years later I find myself working as both a visual artist and poet developing the manuscript for my first chapbook entitled Indigo Season. The Banff Centre for Arts and Culture, has recognized the promise of this work, and as a globally respected incubator for cultural creatives, they have accepted my application for a week-long mini retreat residency in Alberta, Canada.

story:
Hey good people! Nina Serrano and Eva Martinez are asking for your support. We have been working on a powerful anthology coming out of San Francisco’s Mission district.  Poetry in Flight/Poesia en vuelo: Anthology in Celebration of El Tecolote features 69 insightful contemporary poems in Spanish, English and Spanglish by 56 fiery poets speaking with a lyrical passion on equality, inclusion, freedom, justice, gender identity, gentrification and more.  The editors are the late Francisco X. Alarcon, Eva and Nina, with assistance by Harold Terezon. United States Poet Laureate Juan Felipe Herrera penned the foreword. How freaking cool is that!

Your donation will help us cover $1500 in print and design costs. All income from sales will go to support El Tecolote’s important media work.

This unique collection of poetry is highly suitable for classroom use and can be pre-ordered by emailing vuelopoesia@gmail.com. The 140-page book costs $20.00. Orders of 10 or more receive a 10 percent discount. 

For those of you who don’t know El Tecolote, it is a 46-year-old bilingual newspaper based in the heart of the Mission district. Since its inception El Teco has served as a training ground for aspiring journalists. In the 1980s its quarterly literary supplement La Revista literario provided an important pre-Internet publishing space for Latino writers.

El Tecolote is one of the longest running bilingual (Spanish/English) newspaper in the nation. For 46 years a tiny paid staff and a league of amazing volunteers has produced original reporting, turned out a print and web edition, provided journalism training and promoted bilingualism. Pretty amazing, huh?  Check out it out at www.eltecolote.org

story:
Story of My Book

Nourish is about exploring the social relationships that are facilitated by food and cooking. Ascribing sentiment and connection with food is something uniquely human, and the implications of these relationships have impacts on our lives. 

My name is Amenda Lee and I am the author of Nourish. I wrote this book because I wanted to create something that is not only a commentary on our current food relationships, but also is a text that exposes the inequities and harmful societal norms that are present in the food we consume and the routines we have.

My hope is that, in reading this book, you will discover that our relationships with food are very complex. In this book, I hope to instill in you the same sort of passion and excitement that I have for social and personal connections viewed through the lens of food. Ultimately, I want you to see this book as a tool to help you grow your own positive relationship with food or cooking.

 

In this book, you'll learn about the highly connective nature of food and how it helps us relate to others. You'll hear stories such as...

  • How a body-positive social media influencer with over a million followers spanned on her social media started her career
  • The unraveling of the origins of LA’s Korean community’s biggest mysteries — LA Galbi
  • My recovery from the physical and mental toll eating disorders had on my life.

You will love this book if you love food, sociology, and cooking.

Nourish is a nonfiction book that speaks to young and older audiences who want to look at cooking and their unique food relationships in a new way.

What I Need & What You'll Get

This book will be published with New Degree Press. I set up the pre-order tiers to help cover the costs for publishing my book. Money raised will go towards the following:

The editor I will work with to revise and publish my manuscript in April 2021.

The cover design of my book. (The mockups you see currently are a placeholder!)

The layout design for the interior of my book (physical copy, ebook formats).

The copy editing for my book to polish the grammar and spelling prior to publication.

The launch & promotion efforts for my book when I ultimately publish this Spring.


When I pre-sell 120 copies of my book, I will publish a paperback and ebook. When I pre-sell 150 copies of my book, I will also publish a hardcover edition. When I pre-sell 200 copies of my book, I will publish a hardcover edition and an audiobook.


I am also offering some exclusive rewards for people who pre-order my book now:

You will receive a personally signed copy of my book when I publish.

Your name will appear in the Acknowledgments section of my book.

You will receive early access to the Introduction and other excerpts from my book, with the opportunity to review them and give me early feedback!

You will have the opportunity to be highly involved in selecting my book cover and title.

You will be invited to join my Author Community and get behind-the-scenes sneak peeks into the publishing process.

And much more!

 

About the Author

Amenda Lee is currently a junior at the University of Southern California studying Business and Technology Commercialization. 

Amenda has been passionate about food and cooking from a young age. After moving to Los Angeles for college in 2018, she became deeply interested in the intersection of sociology and food, and started to express her creativity through cooking meals for her friends and family. You can find some of Amenda’s favorite recipes on her Instagram page dedicated to cooking, @mendameals.

Amenda loves to spend quality time with her loved ones, specifically over a good meal. Prior to COVID-19, her favorite activity was discovering new eats and restaurants across Los Angeles. In her free time, she also loves to sew and up-cycle clothes. 

For more information, you can connect with Amenda at amendashlee@gmail.com and on Instagram @amendaaa.
 

Risks & Challenges

The biggest challenge with publishing a book is delivering the finished book to the backer, specifically my mailing of the book to you. I have eliminated this risk by including the cost of mailing and shipping the signed copies into each pre-order tier. 

The risk of delivering the pre-sale copies of my book is contingent on the publisher we use. I will be working closely with New Degree Press to make sure we ship the pre-order rewards to you as early as possible. We will keep all pre-sale backers up-to-date as to when my book will publish. You will know when the copies of my book you pre-ordered are expected to ship.
 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

Please share my pre-sale campaign on Facebook, Twitter, and LinkedIn with your friends, family and network. Please use #NourishwithAmenda and tag me as well as my publisher, New Degree Press, so that we can help amplify your efforts.

You can easily share my pre-sale campaign via Indiegogo at the top of the page.

Please share my book with 5 friends, family members, or co-workers who you think would enjoy it via text or direct message on social media.

Thank you so much for of all of your love and support!

Thank again,
Amenda Lee

story:
Short Summary

Musehouse is a non-profit Center for the Literary Arts located in the Chestnut Hill neighborhood of Philadelphia.  Musehouse is quickly becoming known for its smart but unpretentious, warm and welcoming environment where writers of all ages and levels can hone their craft and share their work publicly.  It was founded in September 2011 by Kathleen Sheeder Bonanno, an award winning poet and teacher.  Bonanno’s book, Slamming Open the Door, was among the 10 best-selling books of poetry in America in 2009.  Based on the true story of her daughter’s murder, the book and Bonanno’s subsequent book tour reminded her that creative writing can and does change lives for the better, which is what led her to found Musehouse.  Founded just one short year ago, Musehouse already offers a roster of 20 creative writing courses for authors of all ages and levels of experience in poetry, fiction, non-fiction, and playwriting.  Instructors include published and prize-winning authors and seasoned teachers from local colleges and other literary organizations. 

While Musehouse has created a comfortable and nurturing space, the true magic comes from the writers who arrive for class each week… Elizabeth, 83 years old, always the first to arrive for her poetry class, carrying her respirator and waving a bag of carefully-crafted earrings that she donates as our weekly door prize  … Lola, a homeschooled 12-year-old, feisty, talented, who wants her book of poetry published now …  Tim, scooting in late, carrying his hefty memoir about his life on the battlefield during the Vietnam War … and Veronica, quiet, uncertain, here for the Grief and Loss Writing class where, for the first time, she will write about her son’s death.

To learn more about Musehouse, please follow this link (http://video.whyy.org/video/2230315865) to the May 4, 2012 episode of Friday Arts, a monthly television program on local arts, food, and culture produced by WHYY, Philadelphia's PBS station.

 

What We Need & What You Get

What we need:

  • $5,000 by October 1, 2012 in order to meet our matching grant
  • Funds allow us to pay our teachers, our staff, and our rent
  • All contributions will be doubled by the match

What you get:

  • Signed, original artwork and poetry in notecard, book, and poster form ($25, $50, and $100 contributions)
  • Book title of your choice immortalized in an original painting created for and permanently displayed at Musehouse ($100 contribution)
  • Dinner and conversation with nationally renowned, award winning, best-selling authors in an intimate restaurant environment ($500 and $1,000 contributions)

The Impact

Musehouse supports writers, helping them overcome a variety of obstacles to creative expression and self-sharing, work that enriches the world and changes lives for the better.  By providing quiet time and space, the encouragement and feedback of peers and audience members, and instruction from authors and teachers of distinction, Musehouse helps writers to work and to maximize their talent and the impact of their voice on both themselves and the people with whom they connect.

Musehouse provides a full roster of classes on a wide range of writing forms, from poetry and fiction to journal writing and memoir, along with related activities, such as book making and story-telling.  Specialized genres such as writing for children and young adults, grief and loss writing, and playwriting have also been covered.  Students range in age from young children to senior citizens, and in experience from first time writers to seasoned authors.  We also sponsor free readings, performances, and additional special events on a regular basis.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please remember that, even if you are unable to contribute funds right now, you can still help!  Simply forwarding this email to friends, family members, and others in your personal network who you think might share our passion for writing is greatly appreciated.  Post on Facebook, tweet a link, mention us in a blog, or use the Indiegogo share tools to let people know about our organization and the work we’re doing with and for the literary community.  Thanks so much for your support!

Lisa Marie Rollins has been accepted into the nationally known VONA Voices summer Workshop. http://www.voicesatvona.org/

“The VONA Voices Workshop is dedicated to nurturing developing writers of color. Held at the University of San Francisco each summer, writers come from around the country and around the globe to work with renowned writers of color.”

The tuition for each poet is $500.00. I’ve paid a 100.00 deposit and at our fundraiser on Saturday I raised 123.00 (in collaboration with Maya and Vickie for a total of $370.00). So I’ve got 277.00 to go!! Please help me reach my goal!

Please support this wonderful opportunity for me to write, learn and create in a setting specifically supporting my work.

story:
I’m a ghostwriter with a dream. I want to finish my own novel – a fictionalized version of the life of Elvis Presley’s twin, Jesse. The novel is completely outlined and the first 100 pages are written.

The problem is, I cannot afford the time to stop ghostwriting to finish the novel. It’s been 10 years. Meanwhile I write about 5,000 words a week for other people. All these pesky bills have to get paid somehow so I cannot stop writing for money.
 
I need to write another 400 pages – or 100,000 words. This will take me about 10 weeks. With time flying by so fast – I just turned 64 – I am afraid that I will die with my novel never completed.
 
With a little help from my friends, I hope that I can find the free time this summer to finish my novel.
 
If my goal is not fully reached, I can still buy time to get a good chunk of it done.
 

Here's how it begins:

 

Chapter One

January 8, 1935. 3 a.m.

Lurlene Larue was screaming. Her husband, Tom, was driving as fast as he dared. The old Chevy National truck shuddered with the speed.  They had pulled off the highway and into Tupelo just after midnight and tried to catch some sleep. The trip north was tiring and Lurlene was heavily pregnant. It was a race against time to get to Maine where they had the offer of a free home in return for farm work. Tom’s brother and cousin had opted for California but Tom wisely thought that going North would be a better opportunity because there would not be as many competing for work. Lurlene wasn’t due for another month but the jouncing of the truck along the highway was giving her pains. There hadn’t been a chance for much shuteye. The pains increased and by 2 a.m. Lurlene was moaning and half an hour later, they went in search of a doctor. Tom was worried about the cost and how they would get around the problem of money if he had to pay a doctor. In his mind, birthing was something that took place with the womenfolk helping.

Once they got to Maine, they might have to find a midwife because they didn’t have any female kinfolk there. Just Uncle James but James likely knew someone. Even if they had to use a midwife, she would be willing to wait for her pay. But here in Tupelo, the doctor would want his money up front. Tom’s mind was running around on this train of thought when Lurlene began screaming. “I’m dying. Jesus, Tom, I’m dying.”

Where would he find a doctor?  The night sky was unusually bright, with a blue band of lighter sky casting a dusk-like clarity over the ramshackle sharecropper edge of town. There was a diner that looked like it might be open and Tom slowed down. It might just be the owner cleaning up but it would be someone who could tell him how to get to the doctor’s house. As Tom pulled to a stop, a middle-aged black man emerged from the diner. He didn’t lock the door behind him so it might just be a late night local version of a speakeasy.  Tom wondered sometimes why his mind kept drifting off topic. Who gave a good goddamn who the man was? The important thing was to find the doctor. If Lurlene died, his life would be over.

Tom opened the door and called out, “Hey.”

The black man stopped and replied with his own “Hey.”

“Can you tell me where to find a doctor?” The screaming was all the proof needed for the urgency of his request.

The man said, “Yep. Dr. Hunt lives not too far away.” He gave the directions that involved several right turns, a mile long drive and a couple of left turns. Tom tried to capture the instructions in his mind. He thanked the man and retreated into the truck. Or tried to. Lurlene was stretched out on the seat, whimpering and the blood was flowing from between her legs. A little body, bluetinted from the night sky, was between her tucked up feet. Tom took off his shirt and wrapped the little body in it. The cord was still attached to Lurlene’s insides. He laid the shirt-wrapped baby on her chest as she pulled her knees closer to her so Tom could get into the driver’s seat.

He lurched forward and chanting the instructions, raced to the doctor’s house. Lurlene was patting the baby and Tom could hear a raspy breathing  as well as Lurlene’s murmurs. He saw the house as described and leaving his family in the bloody truck, pounded on the door until a tired-looking woman answered.

“Bill’s not here. He’s over to the Presley place.”

Tom’s head was filled with splintery stars. He wanted to holler, “Who the hell is Presley?” Instead he apologized and asked how he could find the Presley place. He got another set of instructions and jammed himself back into the truck and rattled off in the direction the woman explained to him. His pants were damp from the blood and the afterbirth was out of Lurlene. The baby should have been making more than little mewling sounds by now. He should have picked the child – he realized he didn’t know if it was a boy or a girl – up by the feet and smacked it on the bottom to get it breathing right. But he didn’t dare stop.

The Presley place was easy to find – there were lights flickering in the front window.  Tom stopped the vehicle and ran into the house. The front door opened into a small room that served as a kitchen. It was lit by candle. A curtain with faded red roses swung in the doorway into the back room.  A man came through the kitchen. Older, stern looking, and more than inebriated, the man glared at Tom. “What d’ya want?” he snarled.

“The doctor.”

“Get the hell out of here. My grandson is dead.” He waved a big dirty hand in the direction of the table against the wall. Tom thought, “and my son is likely dead too.” He looked into the box and saw a little corpse naked inside. A boy. His cord cut and tied off about a foot from where it attached to the limp little body. Tom choked on his own tears and went outside. Precious time was being wasted while he stared at the dead baby. Lurlene was sobbing when he got to the truck.

“He’s dead,” Lurlene said. “Ti-Tom is dead.”

“Maybe not. The doctor is inside.” He grabbed the baby and then realized that the cord had not been cut. He took out his knife and cut the baby free from its mother. He looked to see whether it was a boy or not.

It was a boy. He was a boy. Tom leaned down to kiss the boy and realized that he was indeed dead. Maybe he had never breathed at all and the raspy little breath was the sound of his own fear in his ears. He took the baby inside rather than tell Lurlene just yet. Let her have a few more minutes of motherhood. Even if it was not real. In the house, the chaos was still going on in the back room. It was almost 4:30 in the morning according to the clock on the table next to the box. He looked into the box, the anguish of thinking of two little babies who would never live. The baby was pink while Ti-Tom was already turning blue. The random thought passed through Tom’s mind that perhaps the baby had been born dead and the blue tinge was not a reflection of the sky but the baby’s true color. He laid his child down beside the box and placed his hand on his son and the pink baby. Ti-Tom was not as warm as the baby in the box. The baby in the box moved.

Voices rose in the back room and it sounded like the ordeal was almost over and then he heard a male voice proclaim. “It’s a boy and he’s…” and whatever the man said was lost in the baby’s first rebel-yell quality cry. No thought was involved. Tom opened his shirt that covered his baby and held the tiny body in his left hand while he used his right to lift the baby from the box and set him on the shirt while depositing the dead baby in the cardboard box. The baby in the shirt whimpered. He left the dead baby in the box and picking up the shirt, wrapped the new Ti-Tom tightly while he walked towards the truck.

“He’s alive, he’s alive and he’s perfect.”
story_txt:
I’m a ghostwriter with a dream. I want to finish my own novel – a fictionalized version of the life of Elvis Presley’s twin, Jesse. The novel is completely outlined and the first 100 pages are written.

The problem is, I cannot afford the time to stop ghostwriting to finish the novel. It’s been 10 years. Meanwhile I write about 5,000 words a week for other people. All these pesky bills have to get paid somehow so I cannot stop writing for money.
 
I need to write another 400 pages – or 100,000 words. This will take me about 10 weeks. With time flying by so fast – I just turned 64 – I am afraid that I will die with my novel never completed.
 
With a little help from my friends, I hope that I can find the free time this summer to finish my novel.
 
If my goal is not fully reached, I can still buy time to get a good chunk of it done.

Once they got to Maine, they might have to find a midwife because they didn’t have any female kinfolk there. Just Uncle James but James likely knew someone. Even if they had to use a midwife, she would be willing to wait for her pay. But here in Tupelo, the doctor would want his money up front.
